Therefore, we reject Defendant’s argument that it is not sufficient for the indictment to “merely state that the victim was ‘handicapped.’ ” Furthermore, the indictment provided Defendant with enough information to prepare a defense for the offense of felony assault on a handicapped person. See Leonard, _ N.C. App. at _, 711 S.E.2d at 873 (rejecting the defendant’s argument that the indictment was not sufficient because the indictment tracked the relevant language of the statute, listed “the essential elements of the offense[,]” and provided the defendant “with enough information to prepare a defense”); State v. Crisp, 126 N.C. App. 30, 36, 483 S.E.2d 462, 466 (<HOLDING>), appeal dismissed and disc. review denied, 346 <question> Is it necessary for the definition of the crime to be stated in the indictment according to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-32.1(a)? <issues> Whether the definition of the crime needs to be included in the indictment <rules> N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-32.1(a), N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-32.1(e) <analysis> According to the passage, the statute N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-32.1(a) does not require the definition to be an essential element of the crime. Therefore, the argument that it is not sufficient for the indictment to merely state that the victim was 'handicapped' is rejected. The passage also states that the indictment provided enough information for the defendant to prepare a defense for the offense of felony assault on a handicapped person. <answer> No, it is not necessary for the definition of the crime to be stated in the indictment according to N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-32.1(a). The argument that the indictment should include more than just stating that the victim was 'handicapped' is rejected. The indictment provided enough information for the defendant to prepare a defense for the offense. <end>

<context> Id. at 687. At the second stage, the defendant must show that he was prejudiced by the deficient performance. “This requires showing that counsel’s errors were so serious as to deprive the defendant of a fair trial, a trial whose result is rehable.” Id. Villagrana challenges his trial counsel’s failure to investigate adequately and present three potential defense witnesses, Chacon, Suarez, and Tapia. “A lawyer who fails adequately to investigate, and to introduce into evidence, records that demonstrate his client’s factual innocence, or that raise sufficient doubt as to that question to undermine confidence in the verdict, renders deficient performance.” Hart v. Gomez, 174 F.3d 1067, 1070 (9th Cir.1999). Even assuming that Villagrana’s trial counsel’s performance was deficient, Vill (<HOLDING>), amended by 311 F.3d 928 (9th Cir.2002). <question> What is the potential issue raised by Villagrana regarding his trial counsel's performance? <issues> The potential issue raised by Villagrana is his trial counsel's failure to adequately investigate and present defense witnesses. <rules> The rule applicable to this issue is that a lawyer who fails to adequately investigate and introduce into evidence records that demonstrate the client's factual innocence or raise sufficient doubt as to that question undermines the confidence in the verdict. <analysis> In this case, Villagrana challenges his trial counsel's failure to investigate and present three potential defense witnesses. Based on the applicable rule, if it can be shown that the trial counsel's deficient performance in not adequately investigating and presenting these witnesses deprived Villagrana of a fair trial, his conviction could be called into question. <answer> The potential issue raised by Villagrana regarding his trial counsel's performance is the failure to adequately investigate and present defense witnesses. As per the applicable rule, if it is demonstrated that this deficient performance deprived Villagrana of a fair trial, his conviction can be called into question. <end>

Although one of these administrators (Jennifer Bumford) was consulted by Dr. Lloyd when he was conducting his evaluation of plaintiff, it is undisputed that neither of these employees were the ultimate decision-makers with respect to the decision to abolish plaintiffs position. Indeed, when considered in the context of all the evidence, these alleged remarks are too “remote and oblique .... in relation to the employer’s adverse action” to permit a reasonable jury to find for plaintiff. Tomassi v. Insignia Fin. Grp., 478 F.3d 111, 115 (2d Cir.2007), abrogated in part on other grounds by Gross v. FBL Fin. Servs., Inc., 557 U.S. 966, 968-69 (S.D.N.Y.1989) (<HOLDING>). Moreover, given the undisputed facts — <question> What is the legal analysis regarding the alleged remarks made by the administrators in relation to the decision to abolish the plaintiff's position? <issues> Legal analysis of alleged remarks by administrators in relation to the decision to abolish plaintiff's position <rules> Tomassi v. Insignia Fin. Grp., 478 F.3d 111, 115 (2d Cir.2007), abrogated in part on other grounds by Gross v. FBL Fin. Servs., Inc., 557 U.S. 966, 968-69 (S.D.N.Y.1989) <analysis> The alleged remarks made by the administrators (Jennifer Bumford) were considered to be too remote and oblique in relation to the employer's adverse action to permit a reasonable jury to find for the plaintiff, based on the context of all the evidence. Therefore, the legal analysis concludes that the alleged remarks do not support a finding in favor of the plaintiff. <answer> The legal analysis regarding the alleged remarks made by the administrators in relation to the decision to abolish the plaintiff's position is that these remarks are considered too remote and oblique in relation to the employer's adverse action. Based on the context of all the evidence, the remarks do not support a finding in favor of the plaintiff. <end>

Because the January 26 agreement was never memorialized in writing, Innomed must point to evidence in the record as to, inter alia, the terms of the oral contract and the terms that ALZA allegedly breached. Innomed has failed to proffer any evidence as to the terms of the January 26 agreement, so it is impossible to determine whether ALZA breached any of the terms of the agreement when it terminated the Distribution Agreement on March 26. See Khajavi, 100 Cal.Rptr.2d at 646-48 (<HOLDING>). Therefore, no reasonable juror could conclude <question> Based on the information in the given passage, was the January 26 agreement between Innomed and ALZA memorialized in writing? <issues> Whether the January 26 agreement between Innomed and ALZA was memorialized in writing. <rules> The rule is that agreements must be memorialized in writing in order to be enforceable. <analysis> The given passage states that the January 26 agreement was never memorialized in writing. Therefore, the January 26 agreement between Innomed and ALZA was not memorialized in writing. <answer> No, the January 26 agreement between Innomed and ALZA was not memorialized in writing based on the information in the passage. <end>

<context> and the difficulty in detecting the crime, the legislature could have reasonably determined that a severe penalty was required for the offense of disclosing confidential lottery information. Furthermore, we are not free “to set aside the legislative determination as to the appropriate penalty merely because it seems too severe.” State v. Moss-Dwyer, 686 N.E.2d at 112. In light of the presumption of constitutionality of statutes, and the heavy burden on the party asserting unconstitutionality, we are not convinced that the penalty for disclosure of confidential lottery information violates the proportionality provision of the Indiana Constitution. See e.g., Cole v. State, 790 N.E.2d 1049; Balls v. State, 725 N.E.2d 450; see also Ponciano v. State, 851 N.E.2d 305, 308 (Ind.Ct.App.2006) (<HOLDING>); Laughner v. State, 769 N.E.2d 1147 <question> Is the penalty for disclosure of confidential lottery information in violation of the proportionality provision of the Indiana Constitution? <issues> Whether the penalty for disclosure of confidential lottery information violates the proportionality provision of the Indiana Constitution. <rules> Presumption of constitutionality of statutes; heavy burden on the party asserting unconstitutionality. <analysis> Based on the information provided in the passage, the legislature could have reasonably determined that a severe penalty was required for the offense of disclosing confidential lottery information. The court is not free to set aside the legislative determination as to the appropriate penalty just because it seems too severe. In light of the presumption of constitutionality of statutes and the heavy burden on the party asserting unconstitutionality, there is no sufficient evidence to conclude that the penalty for disclosure of confidential lottery information violates the proportionality provision of the Indiana Constitution. Several cases, such as Cole v. State, Balls v. State, Ponciano v. State, and Laughner v. State have upheld the constitutionality of the penalty. Therefore, it is unlikely that the penalty is in violation of the proportionality provision of the Indiana Constitution. <answer> Based on the information provided, there is no sufficient evidence to conclude that the penalty for disclosure of confidential lottery information violates the proportionality provision of the Indiana Constitution. The legislature could have reasonably determined that a severe penalty was required for such offense, and the court cannot set aside the legislative determination. The presumption of constitutionality of statutes and the heavy burden on the party asserting unconstitutionality also support the constitutionality of the penalty. Several cases, including Cole v. State, Balls v. State, Ponciano v. State, and Laughner v. State, have upheld the constitutionality of the penalty. Therefore, it is unlikely that the penalty is in violation of the proportionality provision of the Indiana Constitution. <end>

See Bald Eagle, 189 F.3d at 329-30 (<HOLDING>). As such, the Court rejects Plaintiff's <question> What is the significance of the alleged concealment of conflict of interest and excessive commissions? <issues> The significance of the alleged concealment of conflict of interest and excessive commissions <rules> The materiality requirement <analysis> The alleged concealment of both the conflict of interest and the excessive commissions satisfy the materiality requirement, as stated in Press, 218 F.3d at 130 and Ettinger, 835 F.2d at 1033. <answer> The alleged concealment of both the conflict of interest and the excessive commissions is significant because it satisfies the materiality requirement. This means that under all the circumstances, the omitted fact would have assumed actual significance in the deliberations of the reasonable investor. As per Press, 218 F.3d at 130 and Ettinger, 835 F.2d at 1033. <end>

Other cases reject the theory, taking the position that an alimony decree is not revived by a second separation following the reconciliation, and that a new application to the court is necessary. Brown v. Brown, 210 Ga. 233, 78 S.E.2d 516, 518 (1953); Moody v. Moody, 227 La. 134, 78 So.2d 536, 537 (1955); Hester v. Hester, 239 N.C. 97, 100, 79 S.E.2d 248 (1953); O’Hara v. O’Hara, 46 N.C. App. 819, 266 S.E.2d 59 (1980); Tiffin v. Tiffin, 2 Binn. 202 (Pa. 1809); M’Karracher v. M’Karracher, supra, 3 Yeates 56; Hill v. Hill, 62 Pa. Super. 439 (1916); Lund v. Lund, 6 Utah 2d 425, 315 P.2d 856, 858 (1957); Patterson v. Patterson, 4 D.L.R. 793 (Ont. 1928). See also Hawn v. Hawn, 505 S.W.2d 459, 463 (Mo. App. 1974) (<HOLDING>). In the instant case, the petition for a writ <question> Is a new application to the court necessary if there is a second separation following a reconciliation in the context of an alimony decree? <issues> Whether a new application to the court is necessary in the context of an alimony decree when there is a second separation following a reconciliation. <rules> Case law from various jurisdictions including Brown v. Brown, 210 Ga. 233, 78 S.E.2d 516, 518 (1953); Moody v. Moody, 227 La. 134, 78 So.2d 536, 537 (1955); Hester v. Hester, 239 N.C. 97, 100, 79 S.E.2d 248 (1953); O’Hara v. O’Hara, 46 N.C. App. 819, 266 S.E.2d 59 (1980); Tiffin v. Tiffin, 2 Binn. 202 (Pa. 1809); M’Karracher v. M’Karracher, supra, 3 Yeates 56; Hill v. Hill, 62 Pa. Super. 439 (1916); Lund v. Lund, 6 Utah 2d 425, 315 P.2d 856, 858 (1957); Patterson v. Patterson, 4 D.L.R. 793 (Ont. 1928); N.E. 696 (1911); Justice v. Justice, 108 N.E.2d 874, 876 (Ohio Comm. Pl. 1952); Hawn v. Hawn, 505 S.W.2d 459, 463 (Mo. App. 1974). <analysis> The theory that an alimony decree is revived by a second separation following a reconciliation and a new application to the court is necessary is rejected by case law in various jurisdictions. Brown v. Brown (1953) held that a new application to the court is necessary in such a scenario. This position is also supported by the decisions in Moody v. Moody (1955), Hester v. Hester (1953), O’Hara v. O’Hara (1980), Tiffin v. Tiffin (1809), M’Karracher v. M’Karracher (3 Yeates 56), Hill v. Hill (1916), Lund v. Lund (1957), Patterson v. Patterson (1928), N.E. 696 (1911), Justice v. Justice (1952), and Hawn v. Hawn (1974). Therefore, based on the legal precedent from these cases, it can be concluded that a new application to the court is necessary if there is a second separation following a reconciliation in the context of an alimony decree. <answer> Based on case law from various jurisdictions including Brown v. Brown (1953) and supported by other decisions such as Moody v. Moody (1955) and Hester v. Hester (1953), it can be concluded that a new application to the court is necessary if there is a second separation following a reconciliation in the context of an alimony decree. This position is also supported by case law in O’Hara v. O’Hara (1980), Tiffin v. Tiffin (1809), M’Karracher v. M’Karracher (3 Yeates 56), Hill v. Hill (1916), Lund v. Lund (1957), Patterson v. Patterson (1928), N.E. 696 (1911), Justice v. Justice (1952), and Hawn v. Hawn (1974). Therefore, if there is a second separation after a reconciliation, the parties would need to make a new application to the court in order to address any issues related to the alimony decree. <end>

<context> Kennedy). The judgment of conviction having been vacated, the present defendant is treated as a charged, not as a convicted child pornographer. The question now posed is whether the pretrial condition of curfew with electronic monitoring mandated by the Adam Walsh Act is unconstitutional as applied in view of this court’s finding that electronic monitoring is not needed to avoid flight or any danger to children or to society. The answer: The Adam Walsh Act is unconstitutional as applied to this defendant under present circumstances. B. Constitutionality The Eighth Amendment provides “excessive bail shall not be required.” U.S. amend. VII. This limit of federal authority applies to the states. See Kennedy v. Louisiana, — U.S. —, 128 S.Ct. 2641, 2649, 171 L.Ed.2d 601 (S.D.N.Y.2008) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Crowell, Nos. 06-M1095, <question> Is the pretrial condition of curfew with electronic monitoring mandated by the Adam Walsh Act unconstitutional in this case? <issues> Constitutionality of the pretrial condition of curfew with electronic monitoring mandated by the Adam Walsh Act <rules> The Eighth Amendment's provision against excessive bail <analysis> Based on the court's finding that electronic monitoring is not needed to avoid flight or any danger to children or society, the pretrial condition of curfew with electronic monitoring is deemed unconstitutional in this case. <answer> Yes, the pretrial condition of curfew with electronic monitoring mandated by the Adam Walsh Act is unconstitutional in this case based on the court's finding that it is not needed to avoid flight or any danger to children or society. <end>

<context> Wright contends that the district court erred by sentencing him to consecutive sentences of imprisonment following the revocation of his supervised release because the original plea agreement and sentence provided that the terms of imprisonment be concurrent and co-terminous. The district court did not err because under Ninth Circuit precedent, a district court may impose consecutive sentences after the revocation of supervised release even when the original sentences were concurrent. See United States v. Jackson, 176 F.3d 1175, 1176 (9th Cir.1999). Wright also contends that the district court erred by imposing a term of supervised release following his re-imprisonment. This contention is foreclosed by United States v. Johnson, 529 U.S. 694, 713, 120 S.Ct. 1795, 146 L.Ed.2d 727 (2000) (<HOLDING>). AFFIRMED. ** This disposition is not <question> Did the district court err by sentencing Wright to consecutive sentences of imprisonment following the revocation of his supervised release? <issues> The issue being debated is whether the district court erred in sentencing Wright to consecutive sentences of imprisonment after his supervised release was revoked. <rules> Under Ninth Circuit precedent, a district court may impose consecutive sentences after the revocation of supervised release even when the original sentences were concurrent. <analysis> Based on the Ninth Circuit precedent in United States v. Jackson, the district court did not err in sentencing Wright to consecutive sentences following the revocation of his supervised release, despite the original plea agreement and sentence calling for concurrent terms of imprisonment. <answer> No, the district court did not err in sentencing Wright to consecutive sentences of imprisonment following the revocation of his supervised release. According to Ninth Circuit precedent, the district court has the authority to impose consecutive sentences after the revocation of supervised release, even if the original sentences were concurrent. This is supported by the ruling in United States v. Jackson. Therefore, Wright's contention that the district court erred in this regard is not valid. <end>

<context> See Graham, 490 U.S. at 396, 109 S.Ct. 1865. The undisputed facts in this case demonstrate that Six Feathers continually eluded the officers and took them on a lengthy and ' highly dangerous chase. Near the end of the pursuit, Six Feathers intentionally drove his car directly into Tarrell’s vehicle. Jarman testified that it was his belief that Six Feathers was an “immediate threat.” Dep. of Brett Jarman at 178. Jarman further testified that, after the collision, he believed Six Feathers, as he was backing up and turning his car in Jarman’s direction, intended to run him over. Id. at 179. Based on these undisputed facts, we hold that Jarman’s use of deadly force was objectively reasonable under the circumstances as Jarman knew them to be at that time. See Cole, 993 F.2d at 1333 (<HOLDING>). In denying Jarman’s motion, the District <question> Was Jarman's use of deadly force objectively reasonable under the circumstances? <issues> Whether Jarman's use of deadly force was objectively reasonable under the circumstances <rules> The standard for determining if the use of deadly force is objectively reasonable <analysis> Based on the undisputed facts in this case, including Six Feathers' dangerous chase, intentional collision, and subsequent actions, it can be argued that Jarman's use of deadly force was objectively reasonable under the circumstances. <answer> Yes, based on the undisputed facts in this case, Jarman's use of deadly force can be considered objectively reasonable under the circumstances. <end>

<context> have a number of tools at their disposal in exercising their Section 8(c) rights to express their views on union organizing efforts. An employer is permitted, for example, to express its views about union representation to masses of employees, in mandatory meetings, on company time, so long as such speech does not occur within 24 hours of an election. See Peerless Plywood Co., 107 NLRB 427, 429 (1953); Livingston Shirt Corp., 107 NLRB 400, 409 (1953). Employers may dispatch supervisors to engage in one-on-one discussions during work time with employees about the negative effects of union representation, see, e.g., NLRB v. Lenkurt Elec. Co., 438 F.2d 1102, 1107-08 (9th Cir.1971), and may disseminate written anti-union materials, Beverly Enterprises-Hawaii, Inc., 326 NLRB 335, 336 (1998) (<HOLDING>). Our opinions have faithfully reiterated our <question> What tools do employers have at their disposal to express their views on union organizing efforts? <issues> Tools available to employers for expressing their views on union organizing efforts <rules> Employer rights under Section 8(c) of the National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) <analysis> Employers have several tools available to express their views on union organizing efforts. They can hold mandatory meetings during company time to express their views to employees, as long as it is not within 24 hours of an election. They can also dispatch supervisors to engage in one-on-one discussions during work time with employees, and distribute written anti-union materials. <answer> Employers have a number of tools at their disposal to express their views on union organizing efforts under Section 8(c) of the NLRA. They can hold mandatory meetings and express their views about union representation to employees, as long as it is not within 24 hours of an election. They can also engage supervisors in one-on-one discussions with employees during work time to discuss the negative effects of union representation. Additionally, employers may distribute written anti-union materials to further express their views. <end>

Saverin's argument that Wendy's failed to prevent the occurrence of a condition that permitted them to prematurely terminate the Forbearance and Franchise Agreements ignores this principle. Therefore, Wendy's actions do not constitute a breach of the existing terms of the Forbearance Agreement. <answer> No, Saverin's argument that Wendy's breached the existing terms of the Forbearance Agreement does not hold any legal merit. <context> This is not fee simple. When all reasonable inferences are drawn in favor of the non-moving party, there is a disputed issue of fact as to when and how MassMutual determines its compensation for each SIA involving a single mutual fund. The caselaw is clear that a service provider’s retention of discretion to set compensation can create fiduciary duties under ERISA with respect to its compensation. Generally speaking, a service provider “does not act as a fiduciary with respect to the terms in the service agreement if it does not control the named fiduciary’s negotiation and approval of those terms.” Hecker v. Deere & Co., 556 F.3d 575, 583 (7th Cir.2009) (citing cases); Santomenno v. John Hancock Life Ins. Co., Civ. No. 2:10-ev-01655, 2013 WL 3864395, at *1 (D.N.J. July 24, 2013) (<HOLDING>). However, “after a person has entered into an <question> What specific fiduciary duties can be created under ERISA with respect to compensation? <issues> Determining fiduciary duties under ERISA with respect to compensation <rules> Retention of discretion to set compensation can create fiduciary duties under ERISA <analysis> In this case, there is a disputed issue of fact as to when and how MassMutual determines its compensation for each SIA involving a single mutual fund. The caselaw is clear that a service provider’s retention of discretion to set compensation can create fiduciary duties under ERISA with respect to its compensation. However, a service provider would not act as a fiduciary if it does not control the negotiation and approval of the compensation terms by the named fiduciary. <answer> Under ERISA, fiduciary duties with respect to compensation can be created if a service provider retains discretion to set compensation. However, if the service provider does not control the negotiation and approval of the compensation terms by the named fiduciary, they may not be considered a fiduciary with respect to the compensation terms. <end>

<context> and operation of workmen’s compensation. If an employer and employee are covered by the Act, all their rights and remedies are defined exclusively by the Act. § 52-1-9, N.M.S.A.1978. The interpretation of a statute is a question of law over which this court has de novo review. Babe Houser Motor Co. v. Tetreault, 270 Kan. 502, 506, 14 P.3d 1149 (2000). The fundamental rule of statutory construction is that the intent of the legislature must govern if that intent can be ascertained. Courts presume that the legislature will express its intent through the language of the statutory scheme. When the language of a statute is plain and unambiguous, the court will not speculate about the legislative intent but must give effect to the intent as expressed without determining what the law should or should not be. Biritz v. Williams, 262 Kan. 769, 774, 942 P.2d 25 (1997) (<HOLDING>). In a different factual scenario, this court <question> What is the fundamental rule of statutory construction? <issues> Determining the fundamental rule of statutory construction <rules> The fundamental rule of statutory construction is that the intent of the legislature must govern if that intent can be ascertained <analysis> The fundamental rule of statutory construction requires the court to give effect to the intent of the legislature when it can be determined. The court presumes that the legislature expresses its intent through the language of the statutory scheme. When the language of a statute is plain and unambiguous, the court must give effect to the intent as expressed without speculating about the legislative intent or determining what the law should or should not be. <answer> The fundamental rule of statutory construction is that the intent of the legislature must govern if that intent can be ascertained. When the language of a statute is plain and unambiguous, the court must give effect to the intent as expressed without speculating about the legislative intent or determining what the law should or should not be. <end>

<context> it fails to pay its employees promptly, see Biggs v. (<HOLDING>), cert. denied, 433 U.S. 915, 97 S.Ct. 2988, 53 <question> What is the significance of an employer's failure to pay its employees promptly under the FLSA? <issues> Potential consequences of an employer failing to pay employees promptly under the FLSA <rules> Case law and legal principles related to an employer's failure to pay employees promptly <analysis> The impact of an employer's failure to pay employees promptly on the employer's good faith defense and compliance with FLSA <answer> The failure of an employer to pay its employees promptly under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) can have significant legal consequences. In cases such as Biggs v. Wilson, 828 F.Supp. 774, 780 (E.D.Cal.1991), aff'd, 1 F.3d 1537 (9th Cir.1993), cert. denied, — U.S. -, 114 S.Ct. 902, 127 L.Ed.2d 94 (1994), it has been established that any subsequent failure to promptly pay employees cannot be considered an action taken under an objectively reasonable belief that the State was in compliance with the FLSA. This means that an employer cannot use a good faith defense if they fail to pay employees in a timely manner. Furthermore, an employer's failure to adhere to administrative rulemaking or precedent related to the FLSA can also negate their good faith defense. For example, in cases such as Joiner v. City of Macon, 814 F.2d 1537, 1539 (11th Cir.1987) and Richard v. Marriott Corp., 549 F.2d 303, 306 (4th Cir.), cert. denied, 433 U.S. 915, 97 S.Ct. 2988, employers were unable to reasonably believe that certain employees were excluded from FLSA requirements based on relevant Department of Labor regulations and precedent. Therefore, it is essential for employers to promptly pay their employees in order to maintain good faith defense and compliance with the FLSA. <end>

There is a general consensus among state and federal courts that sentencing information should not be communicated to jurors <answer> No, it is not recommended to inform the jury about the potential punishment in a criminal case. Doherty, 906 F.2d 41, 44 (1st Cir.1990); see also United States v. Gaudin, 515 U.S. 506, 509, 115 S.Ct. 2310, 132 L.Ed.2d 444 (1995). To be material, the statement “need not directly concern an element of the crime” being investigated, “nor need it actually influence the jury.” Doherty, 906 F.2d at 44. Because materiality is a mixed question of fact and law for the jury, Gaudin, 515 U.S. at 512-15, 115 S.Ct. 2310, a court may only decide the issue, as a matter of law, when no reasonable juror could find materiality on the evidence presented, cf. In re Stone & Webster, Inc., Sec. Litig., 414 F.3d 187, 209 (1st Cir.2005) (<HOLDING>). A court may only decide the issue, as a matter of law, when no reasonable juror could find materiality on the evidence presented. <answer> In a grand jury inquiry, a statement is considered material if it does not need to directly concern an element of the crime being investigated, nor does it need to actually influence the jury. Materiality is a mixed question of fact and law for the jury, and a court can only decide the issue as a matter of law when no reasonable juror could find materiality based on the evidence presented. <end>

Zuniga teaches that evidence of guilt can preponderate in favor of conviction but still be insufficient to prove the elements of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt. Zuniga, 144 S.W.3d at 485. Hunt, 324 N.C. 343, 378 S.E.2d 754, <question> What is the significance of introducing a prior inconsistent statement in a criminal trial? <issues> The significance of introducing a prior inconsistent statement in a criminal trial <rules> The legal principles related to the introduction of prior inconsistent statements in criminal trials <analysis> The analysis of how the introduction of a prior inconsistent statement may impact the fairness of the trial and the jury's determination of guilt or innocence <answer> The significance of introducing a prior inconsistent statement in a criminal trial is that it may potentially impact the fairness of the trial and the jury's determination of guilt or innocence. However, introducing a prior inconsistent statement solely for the purpose of introducing hearsay evidence against the defendant would be considered an abuse of the impeachment rule. It is important for the jury to understand the distinction between impeachment and substantive evidence, and not to ignore or misconstrue the subtle difference. In addition, the Fourth Circuit, as previously mentioned, has rejected the "elimination” standard. See Firestone Fibers & Textiles, 515 F.3d at 313. 8 . See also Baker v. In sum, whether Odettes’ delay in filing suit against defendants is taken as six years or three, it was clearly unreasonable in the circumstances of this case. Odettes is therefore barred from recovering damages from any of these defendants for any infringement occurring before June 29,1995. An appropriate Order has already issued. The Clerk is directed to send copies of this Memorandum Opinion to all counsel of record. 1 . A more complete recitation of the facts appears in a previous Memorandum Opinion in this case. In this case, Odettes' delay in filing suit, whether it be six years or three, is considered unreasonable. Additionally, the defendants have suffered prejudice from this delay. In this case, Odettes' delay, whether it be six years or three, was considered unreasonable, and the defendants suffered prejudice as a result. Therefore, Odettes is barred from recovering damages for any infringement occurring before June 29, 1995. <end>

Quinley’s testimony was sufficient evidence for the jury to find that appellant exclusively possessed the stolen rifles recently after they were stolen. Appellant’s reliance on Smith v. Commonwealth, 247 Va. 157, 439 S.E.2d 409 (1994), is misplaced. Smith involved the application of the exclusive possession inference to the Commonwealth’s charge of grand larceny of a truck based solely upon the defendant’s possession of a checkbook and knives which the owner of the truck had left in the truck but had not seen for months prior to the theft. In Smith, the evidence failed to prove that the truck, checkbook, and knives were stolen at the same time. Cf. Williams v. Commonwealth, 188 Va. 583, 597, 50 S.E.2d 407, 414 (1948) (<HOLDING>). Commonwealth relates to the appellant's possession of the stolen rifles <answer> The case Smith v. Commonwealth is not relevant to the appellant's possession of the stolen rifles. In Smith, the court dealt with a different situation involving the application of the exclusive possession inference to a charge of grand larceny of a truck. The evidence in Smith failed to establish that the truck, checkbook, and knives were stolen at the same time. Therefore, the court found that Smith did not support appellant's argument regarding the possession of the stolen rifles. <end>

<context> at issue is a person’s “right to cut off questioning.” Id., at 474 [86 S.Ct. at 1627]. Through the exercise of his option to terminate questioning he can control the time at which questioning occurs, the subjects discussed, and the duration of the interrogation. The requirement that law enforcement authorities must respect a person’s exercise of that option counteracts the coercive pressures of the custodial setting. We therefore conclude that the admissibility of statements obtained after the person in custody has decided to remain silent depends under Miranda, on whether his “right to cut off questioning” was “scrupulously honored.” Mosley, 423 U.S. at 103-04, 96 S.Ct. 321 (footnote omitted). Compare Edwards v. Arizona, 451 U.S. 477, 484-85, 101 S.Ct. 1880, 68 L.Ed.2d 378 (1981) (<HOLDING>). <context> the EAJA for determining whether a party is entitled to fees. Id. at 456. Accordingly, in Claro, we discussed at length when a party has “incurred” fees for purposes of the EAJA. Id. After examining the definition of “incurred” in Webster’s Dictionary — “to become liable or subject to,” or to “bring down upon oneself’ — and Black’s Law "Dictionary — “to suffer to bring on oneself a liability or expense,” id. at 456 (citations and brackets omitted), we concluded that the general rule is that fees are incurred “when the litigant has a legal obligation to pay them.” Id. at 464-65 (citing Sec. Exch. Comm’n v. Comserv Corp., 908 F.2d 1407, 1414-15 (8th Cir.1990) (<HOLDING>); United States v. This means that the litigant becomes liable or subject to the fees, or brings the liability or expense upon themselves. <end>

See United States v. Layman, 116 F.3d 105, 108 (4th Cir.1997) (<HOLDING>). Layman, 116 F.3d 105, 108 (4th Cir.1997) <analysis> According to the holding in United States v. This is based on the holding in United States v. Layman, 116 F.3d 105, 108 (4th Cir.1997), which states that the district court must reimpose these obligations in open court during the revocation hearing. <end>

<context> While not specifically enumerated in the terms of Article II, section 3 of Montana’s constitution, the opportunity to pursue employment is, nonetheless, necessary to enjoy the right to pursue life’s basic necessities.” Wadsworth v. In Wadsworth, the Montana Supreme Court held “that the opportunity to pursue employment, while not specifically enumerated as a fundamental constitutional right under Article II, section 3 of Montana’s constitution is, notwithstanding, necessarily encompassed within it and is itself a fundamental right because it is a right ‘without which other constitutionally guaranteed rights would have little meaning.’ ” Id. (quoting Butte Community Union v. Lewis, 219 Mont. 426, 430, 712 P.2d 1309, 1311-13 (1986) (<HOLDING>)). Plaintiffs want to equate the opportunity to <question> What is the legal analysis of the right to pursue employment in Montana based on the passage? <issues> The legal analysis of the right to pursue employment in Montana <rules> Article II, section 3 of Montana’s constitution <analysis> The opportunity to pursue employment is considered necessary to enjoy the right to pursue life’s basic necessities, even though it is not specifically enumerated in the terms of Article II, section 3 of Montana’s constitution. The Montana Supreme Court, in the case of Wadsworth v. Montana, held that the opportunity to pursue employment is a fundamental right because it is a right 'without which other constitutionally guaranteed rights would have little meaning.' This analysis is based on the interpretation of Article II, section 3 and the precedent set by Butte Community Union v. Lewis. <answer> The legal analysis of the right to pursue employment in Montana, based on the passage, is that while it is not specifically listed as a fundamental right in Article II, section 3 of Montana's constitution, the opportunity to pursue employment is considered necessary to enjoy the right to pursue life's basic necessities. This analysis is supported by the Montana Supreme Court's decision in Wadsworth v. Montana, where it was held that the opportunity to pursue employment is a fundamental right because it is a right 'without which other constitutionally guaranteed rights would have little meaning.' This interpretation is based on the precedent set by Butte Community Union v. Lewis. <end>

The court reasoned that when, as with the FCRA, “the statutory cause of action does not require proof of actual damages, a plaintiff can suffer a violation of the statutory right without suffering actual damages.” Id. at 413; see also 15 U.S.C. § 1681n(a)(1)(A) (“Any person who willfully fails to comply with any requirement imposed [under the FCRA] with respect to any consumer is liable to that consumer in an amount equal to the sum of — any actual damages sustained by the consumer as a result of the failure or damages of not less than $100 and not more than $1000.” (emphasis added); Bateman v. Am. Multi-Cinema, Inc., 623 F.3d 708, 719 (9th Cir.2010) (<HOLDING>); Montgomery v. Wells Fargo Bank, C12-3895 TEH, <question> When can a plaintiff sue for willful violations? <issues> The specific aspect being debated is whether a plaintiff can sue for willful violations without showing actual harm. <rules> According to Robins v. Spokeo, Inc., 742 F.3d 409, 412 (9th Cir.2014), when the statutory cause of action does not require proof of actual damages, a plaintiff can suffer a violation of the statutory right without suffering actual damages. <analysis> In this case, the court reasoned that the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), which does not require proof of actual damages, allows a plaintiff to sue for willful violations without showing actual harm. This is supported by the language in 15 U.S.C. § 1681n(a)(1)(A), which states that any person who willfully fails to comply with the FCRA requirements is liable to the consumer in an amount equal to any actual damages sustained or damages of not less than $100 and not more than $1000. <answer> A plaintiff can sue for willful violations without showing actual harm if the statutory cause of action, such as the one provided by the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), does not require proof of actual damages. In such cases, a violation of the statutory right can be established without the presence of actual damages. <end>

Plaintiff alternatively relies on the principle that a “continuously operative dan gerous condition” may form the basis for a claim under the Act’s intentional-tort exception. The Michigan Supreme Court has observed that “[a] continuously operative dangerous condition may form the basis of a claim under the intentional tort exception only if the employer knows the condition will cause an injury and refrains from informing the employee about it.” Giles v. Ameritech, 468 Mich. 897, 660 N.W.2d 72, 73 (2003) (emphasis added) (citing Travis, 551 N.W.2d at 145); Alexander, 660 N.W.2d 67; Upsher v. Grosse Pointe Pub. Sch. Sys., 285 F.3d 448, 455-56 (6th Cir. 2002) (<HOLDING>). The Michigan Supreme Court has specifically stated that a continuously operative dangerous condition can only form the basis of a claim if the employer knows the condition will cause injury and intentionally keeps the employee uninformed. <answer> A continuously operative dangerous condition can form the basis for a claim under the intentional tort exception if the employer is aware that the condition will cause injury and intentionally withholds this information from the employee. <end>

The issue of whether Davis was entitled to prejudgment interest had already been determined and any countervailing equities should not have been a consideration for the Cibola County court. The surety bond states that Safeco is to pay claimants “such sum or sums as may be justly due claimant” following a lawsuit. It has long been black-letter law that “[i]nterest normally commences to run against the principal from the date that he violates his obligation and, since the surety is liable for the principal’s entire debt, he will be hable also for such interest on the debt.” Arthur A. <context> for the Tulsa Credit Union robbery, Herron testified that Deandre helped steal a car for the robbery, drove the coconspirators to the credit union, and acted as a getaway driver. Deandre submits two cases from this court for the proposition that “mere gang membership, by itself, is not evidence of criminal activity.” He cites United States v. Deandre’s <question> What specific legal rules, laws, or principles are relevant to the issue? <issues> The issue is whether there is sufficient evidence to establish three conspiracies in the Tulsa Credit Union robbery, the IBC Bank robbery, and the CVS Pharmacy robbery. <rules> To determine whether there is sufficient evidence to establish a conspiracy, the court will consider the following elements: (1) an agreement between two or more persons to accomplish an unlawful objective; (2) the defendant's knowing and voluntary participation in the conspiracy; and (3) an overt act in furtherance of the conspiracy. <analysis> In the case of the Tulsa Credit Union robbery, Herron testified that Deandre helped steal a car for the robbery, drove the coconspirators to the credit union, and acted as a getaway driver. As for the IBC Bank robbery, it has been concluded in Vernon's appeal that there was insufficient evidence to establish a conspiracy to rob that bank. In the case of the Tulsa Credit Union robbery, testimony from Herron provides evidence of an agreement and Deandre's participation as a getaway driver. However, it has been concluded in Vernon's appeal that there was insufficient evidence to establish a conspiracy in the IBC Bank robbery. Additionally, the CVS Pharmacy robbery was not even charged in the indictment. Therefore, there is sufficient evidence to establish a conspiracy in the Tulsa Credit Union robbery, but not in the IBC Bank robbery or the CVS Pharmacy robbery. <end>

This standard is more deferential than the de novo review applied to questions of law, but less deferential than the substantial evidence standard applied to questions of fact. It requires that the facts and circumstances, as presented in the search warrant application, provide a substantial basis for determining that there is probable cause to believe that a search will uncover evidence of wrongdoing. <end>

Two caveats must accompany the League court’s articulation of what constitutes an adequate discussion of mitigation measures under the Compact. First, while NEPA caselaw may provide persuasive authority for interpreting the Compact, it is not controlling. Under NEPA, the duty to study possible mitigation measures stems from the statute’s requirement that the unavoidable adverse effects of a project be studied. See Robertson v. Methow Valley Citizens Council, 490 U.S. 332, 351-52, 109 S.Ct. 1835, 104 L.Ed.2d 351 (1989) (<HOLDING>). Under the Compact, an EIS needs to include <question> What constitutes an adequate discussion of mitigation measures under the Compact? <issues> Determining the requirements for an adequate discussion of mitigation measures under the Compact. <rules> The court's articulation in the League case. <analysis> The court in the League case held that an EIS must include, at a minimum, a 'reasonably complete' discussion of mitigation measures including 'analytical data' regarding whether the available measures would achieve the required result. However, it is important to note that NEPA caselaw may provide persuasive authority for interpreting the Compact, but it is not controlling. <answer> An adequate discussion of mitigation measures under the Compact requires the inclusion of a 'reasonably complete' discussion of mitigation measures, along with 'analytical data' on whether the available measures would achieve the required result. However, it is important to consider that NEPA caselaw, while persuasive, is not controlling in interpreting the Compact. <end>

In unambiguous terms, the Court held that “Miranda applies only to cases in which the trial began after the date of our decision one week ago.” Id. at 721, 86 S.Ct. 1772. The rule did not apply “retroactively,” that is, to convictions which were already final, nor did it apply to cases tried before Miranda’s effective date. Id. at 731-32, 86 S.Ct. 1772. However, even for statements elicited pre-Miranda, the rule would henceforth apply “to persons whose trials had not begun as of June 13, 1966.” Id. at 734, 86 S.Ct. 1772; see also Frazier v. This means that the Miranda warnings, which inform individuals of their constitutional rights during custodial interrogations, only need to be given in cases where the trial started after the Miranda decision. Therefore, Miranda does not apply retroactively to convictions that were already final before Miranda was decided, nor does it apply to cases tried before Miranda's effective date. <answer> Miranda applies only to cases in which the trial began after the date of the Miranda decision. Neither passes muster. According to the Virgin Islands Supreme Court, Kendall’s opinion was punishable because it “called the very integrity of [its mandamus] decision into question” by “blatantly accusing], without proof, the Justices ... of gross dereliction of their sworn duties and of committing illegal acts.” Yet Kendall’s criticism of the decision to issue mandamus — even if it unfairly impugned the Justices’ motives — is simply not enough. His after-the-fact critique “could not affect [the Justices’] ability to [fairly] decide” how to rule on the petition for a writ of mandamus. Pennekamp, 328 U.S. at 348 (<HOLDING>). However, the analysis shows that Kendall's after-the-fact critique could not affect the Justices' ability to fairly decide on the petition for a writ of mandamus. <answer> The Virgin Islands Supreme Court concluded that Kendall's opinion posed a clear and present danger to the fairness of the Ford case because it accused the Justices of gross dereliction of their duties and illegal acts, thereby allegedly calling into question the integrity of their mandamus decision. Although McNiff did not involve a minor settlement fund, its reasoning and holding nonetheless apply here. Minor settlements, like private trusts, are not among the enumerated assets that are not to be considered available resources. Minn.Stat. §§ 256B.06, subd. l(13)(a); 256B.07. Under Minn.Stat. § 645.19 (1986), “[exceptions expressed in a law shall be construed to exclude all others.” In the absence of any compelling authority to the contrary, the fact that minor settlement funds are not specifically excepted from consideration as available resources is dispositive. See also Brooks, 405 N.W.2d at 433-34 (<HOLDING>). II Hennepin County’s claim for reimbursement <question> Are minor settlement funds considered as available resources under the law? <issues> Whether minor settlement funds are considered as available resources under the law. <rules> The Trust assets are intended to be included among the available resources of potential recipients. Therefore, it can be concluded that minor settlement funds are considered as available resources under the law. <answer> Based on the information provided in the passage, minor settlement funds are considered as available resources under the law. The legislature intended trust assets to be included among the available resources of potential recipients, and this includes minor settlement funds. McNiff case reasoning and holding apply to this situation. Additionally, the absence of any compelling authority to the contrary and the fact that minor settlement funds are not specifically excepted from consideration as available resources further support this conclusion. <end>

Where the "settling parties have failed to allocate, the trial court must allocate in the manner which is most advantageous to the nonsettling party." Dillingham Construction v. Nadel Partnership, 64 Cal.App.4th 264, 287, 75 Cal.Rptr.2d 207 (1998); see also Knox v. County of Los Angeles, 109 Cal.App.3d 825, 835, 167 Cal.Rptr. 463 (1980) (<HOLDING>). The rule that applies in such cases is that when the settling parties have failed to allocate, the trial court must allocate in the manner which is most advantageous to the nonsettling party. This rule was established in the case of Dillingham Construction v. Nadel Partnership, 64 Cal.App.4th 264, 287, 75 Cal.Rptr.2d 207 (1998). Another relevant case is Knox v. County of Los Angeles, 109 Cal.App.3d 825, 835, 167 Cal.Rptr. 463 (1980). The attorney for the party should provide testimony regarding the allocation of the settlement. <end>

In that case, the Court identified two exceptions to the class of one theory of equal protection. See Engquist, 553 U.S. at 603-05, 128 S.Ct. 2146; Avila v. Pappas, 591 F.3d 552, 554 (7th Cir.2010) (discussing Engquist). First, Engquist held that “disputes related to a public employee’s interactions with superiors or co-workers never may be litigated as class-of-one claims under the equal protection clause.” Avila, 591 F.3d at 554. Second, it held that “class-of-one claims cannot rest on governmental activity that is discretionary by design,” such as prosecutorial charging decisions. Id.; see also Srail v. Village of Lisle, 588 F.3d 940, 945 (7th Cir.2009) (<HOLDING>). The second exception is that class-of-one claims cannot rest on governmental activity that is discretionary by design, such as prosecutorial charging decisions. <answer> The exceptions to the class of one theory of equal protection are identified in the Engquist case. The first exception is that disputes related to a public employee's interactions with superiors or co-workers can never be litigated as class-of-one claims under the equal protection clause. The second exception is that class-of-one claims cannot rest on governmental activity that is discretionary by design, such as prosecutorial charging decisions. <end>

The plaintiff must also establish that they were subjected to unwelcome sexual harassment, meaning that the conduct was unwanted or unconsented to. Furthermore, it must be demonstrated that the harassment was based on sex, meaning that it was motivated by the plaintiff's gender. The plaintiff must then show that the harassment was severe or pervasive enough to create an abusive educational environment, meaning that it significantly interfered with their ability to participate in their education. Finally, the plaintiff must establish some basis for institutional liability, meaning that the educational institution can be held responsible for the harassment.

The legal cases referenced in the passage, including Kinman v. Omaha Public Sch. Dist., Seamons v. Snow, Brown v. Hot, Sexy & Safer Prods., Inc., Nicole M. v. Martinez Unified Sch. Dist., and Oona, R.S. v. McCaffrey, provide additional guidance and authority on the elements required to prove a claim of sexual harassment in an educational setting. <answer> The specific aspects being debated or questioned in the legal passage are the elements required to establish a claim of sexual harassment in an educational setting. To successfully prove a claim of sexual harassment, the plaintiff must demonstrate that they belong to a protected group, were subject to unwelcome sexual harassment based on their sex, experienced harassment that was sufficiently severe or pervasive to alter the conditions of their education and create an abusive educational environment, and establish some basis for institutional liability. The legal rules relevant to the issue are the five elements mentioned above. To analyze the issue, it is important to consider the evidence and arguments presented for each of these elements, as well as the guidance provided by the referenced legal cases. <end>

<context> WL 1468435, at *3 (S.D.Ohio Mar. 30, 2015) ("Upon default and the acceleration of the loan, the maturity date advances and any subsequent payment is no longer considered a voluntary prepayment. United Merchants and Mfrs., Inc. v. <question> What is the general rule regarding the collection of a prepayment premium upon default and acceleration of a loan? <issues> The general rule regarding the collection of a prepayment premium upon default and acceleration of a loan. <rules> Upn default and the acceleration of the loan, the maturity date advances and any subsequent payment is no longer considered a voluntary prepayment. The lender forfeits the collection of a prepayment premium unless the parties' agreement contains a 'clear and unambiguous' clause requiring payment of the prepayment premium upon default and acceleration. <analysis> The general rule is that when a loan is in default and has been accelerated, any subsequent payment is no longer considered a voluntary prepayment. The lender forfeits the collection of a prepayment premium unless the parties' agreement contains a 'clear and unambiguous' clause requiring payment of the prepayment premium upon default and acceleration. This rule was created to address the problem of borrowers intentionally defaulting to acquire the right to prepay without penalty. As a result, lenders began including provisions in loan documents to ensure that the prepayment penalty would still be enforceable after default and acceleration. <end>

It is through immunity statutes supplanting the privilege that Legislatures have attempted to ease such tensions." Attorney General v. Colleton, 387 Mass. 790, 444 N.E.2d 915, 918 (1982) (citation omitted). 6 . 3 Whinery, supra note 4, § 43.56; see also City of Hollywood v. Washington, 384 So.2d 1315, 1319 (Fla.Dist.Ct.App.1980) ("Immunity from prosecution is a creature of statute."). Professor Whinery cites Texas as an example of a jurisdic tion where immunity is not statutory; instead, it is "derived from the so-called inherent power of prosecuting attorneys." 3 Whinery, supra note 4, § 43.56 & n. 6. 7 . Accord Hunter v. State, 63 Okl.Cr. 24, 31, 72 P.2d 399, 402 (1937) (<HOLDING>); Eden v. State, 54 Okl.Cr. 265, 267, 21 P.2d <question> What are immunity statutes and how do they relate to the privilege against self-incrimination? <issues> Definition and relationship between immunity statutes and the privilege against self-incrimination <rules> The privilege against self-incrimination and the role of immunity statutes <analysis> Immunity statutes are laws enacted by legislatures to ease tensions between the privilege against self-incrimination and the legitimate demands of the government to compel citizens to testify. These statutes provide individuals with immunity from prosecution in exchange for their testimony in certain legal proceedings. Immunity is a creature of statute and varies from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. In some jurisdictions, like Texas, immunity is derived from the inherent power of prosecuting attorneys. <answer> Immunity statutes are laws enacted by legislatures to address the tensions between the privilege against self-incrimination and the government's need to obtain testimony from citizens. These statutes grant individuals immunity from prosecution in exchange for their testimony. The privilege against self-incrimination allows individuals to refuse to answer questions in legal proceedings if their answers may incriminate them. However, immunity statutes provide a way to overcome this privilege by offering legal protection from being charged with crimes based upon their compelled testimony. The case of Attorney General v. Colleton highlights the role of immunity statutes in easing these tensions. It is important to note that immunity from prosecution is a creature of statute, meaning it is created and defined by statutes rather than being inherent in the legal system. Different jurisdictions may have variations in their immunity statutes. For example, Professor Whinery cites Texas as a jurisdiction where immunity is not statutory but is derived from the inherent power of prosecuting attorneys. <end>

Next, the Joneses dispute the district court’s dismissal of their third claim, breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing under the Uniform Commercial Code (“UCC”), as adopted by Virginia, which they based on Defendant’s alleged breaches of contract discussed supra. Crestar Bank, 248 Va. 265, 448 S.E.2d 399, 402 (1994). Second, even if the deed of trust falls under the UCC as the Joneses argue, their claim fails because it was pled as a separate tort claim. First, the UCC does not apply to transfers of real property. Second, even if the deed of trust falls under the UCC as the Joneses argue, their claim fails because it was pled as a separate tort claim. <answer> The Joneses' claim for breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing fails for two reasons. First, the UCC does not apply to transfers of real property. Second, even if the deed of trust falls under the UCC, their claim fails because it was pled as a separate tort claim. <end>

<context> other than dismissal, which entails an analysis of other sanctions; and (6) the meritoriousness of the claim. Poulis v. State Farm Fire and Cas. Co., 747 F.2d 863, 868 (3d Cir.1984); see also Emerson v. Thiel Coll., 296 F.3d 184, 190 (3d Cir.2002); Huertas v. United States Dep’t of Educ., 408 Fed.Appx. 639 (3d Cir.2010) (not published). The court must balance the factors and need not find that all of them weigh against plaintiff in order to dismiss the action. Emerson, 296 F.3d at 190 (3d Cir. 2002). Because dismissal for failure to prosecute involves a factual inquiry, it can be appropriate even if some of the Poulis factors are not satisfied. Hicks v. Feeney, 850 F.2d 152, 156 (3d Cir.1988); Curtis T. Bedwell & Sons, Inc. v. Int’l Fidelity Ins. Co., 843 F.2d 683, 696 (3d Cir.1988) (<HOLDING>). IV. DISCUSSION The court finds that the <question> What factors does the court consider when deciding to dismiss an action for failure to prosecute? <issues> Factors considered for dismissal for failure to prosecute <rules> Poulis factors: (1) the extent of the party's personal responsibility; (2) the prejudice to the adversary caused by the failure to meet scheduling orders and respond to discovery; (3) a history of dilatoriness; (4) whether the conduct of the party or the attorney was willful or in bad faith; (5) the effectiveness of sanctions other than dismissal; (6) the meritoriousness of the claim <analysis> The court must balance the Poulis factors and need not find that all of them weigh against the plaintiff in order to dismiss the action. Even if some of the Poulis factors are not satisfied, dismissal for failure to prosecute can still be appropriate. <answer> The court considers several factors when deciding to dismiss an action for failure to prosecute. These factors, known as the Poulis factors, include: (1) the extent of the party's personal responsibility; (2) the prejudice to the adversary caused by the failure to meet scheduling orders and respond to discovery; (3) a history of dilatoriness; (4) whether the conduct of the party or the attorney was willful or in bad faith; (5) the effectiveness of sanctions other than dismissal; and (6) the meritoriousness of the claim. The court must balance these factors and does not need to find that all of them weigh against the plaintiff in order to dismiss the action. Even if some of the Poulis factors are not satisfied, dismissal for failure to prosecute can still be appropriate. <end>

Elridge, 424 U.S. 319, 332, 96 S.Ct. 893, 47 L.Ed.2d 18 (1976). Due process calls only for “protections as the particular situation demands.” Mathews, 424 U.S. at 334, 96 S.Ct. 893. Due process does not always require “a hearing closely approximating a judicial trial____” Id. at 333, 96 S.Ct. 893. This is not a case where “the evidence consists of testimony of individuals whose memory might be faulty or who, in fact, might be perjurers or persons motivated by malice, vindictiveness, intolerance, prejudice, or jealousy.” Business Commc’ns, 739 F.3d at 380 (<HOLDING>). <context> The continuing violation doctrine “extends the limitations period for all claims of discriminatory acts committed under an ongoing policy of discrimination even if those acts, standing alone, would have been barred by the statute of limitations.” Quinn v. Green Tree Credit Corp., 159 F.3d 759, 765 (2d. Cir.1998) (internal citations and quotations omitted). In this regard, a claim for hostile work environment, “will not be time barred if all acts constituting the claim are part of the same unlawful practice and at least one act falls within the filing period.” Morgan, 536 U.S. 101, 122 S.Ct. 2061, 153 L.Ed.2d 106, at. Acts occurring outside the limitations period that are significantly far apart from each other are “fatal” to a continuing violation argument. See Quinn, 159 F.3d at 766 (<HOLDING>). In addition, it is well-settled in the Second <question> What is the continuing violation doctrine and how does it apply to claims of discriminatory acts? <issues> Understanding the continuing violation doctrine and its application to claims of discriminatory acts <rules> The continuing violation doctrine extends the limitations period for all claims of discriminatory acts committed under an ongoing policy of discrimination. A claim for hostile work environment will not be time barred if all acts constituting the claim are part of the same unlawful practice and at least one act falls within the filing period. <analysis> The continuing violation doctrine allows individuals to bring claims for discriminatory acts that were committed as part of an ongoing policy of discrimination, even if those acts occurred outside the normal statute of limitations. It recognizes that in cases of ongoing discrimination, individual acts may not be considered significant on their own, but can contribute to a continuous pattern of discrimination. Additionally, it provides a framework for determining whether a claim for hostile work environment is time barred or not, based on whether all acts constituting the claim are part of the same unlawful practice and if at least one act falls within the filing period. <answer> The continuing violation doctrine extends the limitations period for all claims of discriminatory acts committed under an ongoing policy of discrimination. This means that even if individual acts of discrimination would normally be barred by the statute of limitations, they can still be considered part of a continuing violation if they are part of an ongoing policy of discrimination. For example, in a claim for hostile work environment, the doctrine allows the claim to be considered valid if all acts constituting the claim are part of the same unlawful practice and at least one act falls within the filing period. It is important to note that acts occurring outside the limitations period that are significantly far apart from each other can be fatal to a continuing violation argument. Overall, the continuing violation doctrine provides a framework for addressing cases of ongoing discrimination and ensuring that individuals have the opportunity to seek legal remedies. <end>

<context> that the debtors filed the functional equiv alent of a monthly net income statement in the form of Schedule J. This is too little and too late. Schedule J deals with a debtor’s current expenditures. In the process, it responds to a different filing requirement, contained in 11 U.S.C. § 521(a)(l)(B)(ii). Although line 20 of Schedule J is called a “Statement of Monthly Net Income” and the advisory committee note to the official bankruptcy forms states that this line was added to Schedule J in 2005 “as required by § 521(a)(l)(B)(v),” there is no reason to think that Schedule J is a proxy for the statement of current monthly income required by section 521(a)(l)(B)(v). In fact, the case law suggests the opposite conclusion. See, e.g., In re Turner, 384 B.R. 852, 856 (Bankr.D.Colo.2008) (<HOLDING>). We need not probe this point too deeply. <question> What is the purpose of Schedule J in bankruptcy filings? <issues> Understanding the purpose of Schedule J in bankruptcy filings <rules> Relevant sections of the bankruptcy code regarding Schedule J <analysis> Analyzing the purpose of Schedule J based on the provided information <answer> Schedule J in bankruptcy filings serves as a means for debtors to provide information about their current expenditures. It is a required filing under section 11 U.S.C. § 521(a)(l)(B)(ii), which mandates the disclosure of a debtor's monthly net income. Although Schedule J may include a line called 'Statement of Monthly Net Income,' it is not considered a proxy for the statement of current monthly income required by section 521(a)(l)(B)(v). Case law, such as In re Turner, 384 B.R. 852, 856 (Bankr.D.Colo.2008), supports the conclusion that Schedule J and the statement of current monthly income serve distinct purposes. Therefore, debtors must fulfill their obligation to file both the functional equivalent of a monthly net income statement and the statement of current monthly income. Filing Schedule J alone is insufficient and may be considered too little and too late. <end>

This requirement was established in cases such as Melendez-Diaz v. Massachusetts and Davis v. Washington, where the Court rejected Bourjaily's reasoning and emphasized the need for independent analysis of 'testimonial' statements. <end>

<context> In his pleadings, Ordonez alleged that Johnson had been negligent per se based on his failure to maintain an assured clear distance between the two vehicles as required by statute. At the close of Ordo-nez’s case, McCurdy moved for a directed verdict on that claim, alleging that Ordonez failed to present any evidence supporting a finding of negligence per se. The trial court entered a directed verdict on Ordonez’s negligence per se claims. At the charge conference, Ordonez requested an instruction on the negligence per se issue, which the trial court refused. Under certain circumstances, failure to appeal an added assessment, in itself, may support a conclusion that the municipality is entitled to a hearing-on the issue of change in value under the Freeze Act. Here, however, defendant has provided no explanation of the added assessment, and the Steinhart Certification makes no reference to the added assessment as evidencing that a change in value occurred as of October 1, 2000. Plaintiffs failure to appeal does not compensate for defendant’s failure to present any proofs that the “alterations” which were the basis for the added assessment resulted in a substantial and meaningful change in the value of the subject property. Cf. United States Postal Serv. v. Town of Kearny, 19 N.J.Tax 282 (Tax 2001) (<HOLDING>). Defendant has not provided the court with any <question> What is the significance of failure to appeal an added assessment under the Freeze Act? <issues> The significance of failure to appeal an added assessment under the Freeze Act <rules> Under certain circumstances, failure to appeal an added assessment may support a conclusion that the municipality is entitled to a hearing on the issue of change in value under the Freeze Act. <analysis> In this specific case, the defendant has not provided any explanation of the added assessment, and there is no reference to the added assessment in the Steinhart Certification as evidence of a change in value. Therefore, the plaintiffs' failure to appeal does not compensate for the defendant's failure to present any proofs that the alterations resulting in the added assessment had a substantial and meaningful change in the value of the subject property. <answer> The significance of failure to appeal an added assessment under the Freeze Act is that, under certain circumstances, it may support the municipality's entitlement to a hearing on the issue of change in value. However, in this case, the defendant failed to provide any explanation of the added assessment, and the Steinhart Certification does not reference the added assessment as evidence of a change in value. Therefore, the plaintiffs' failure to appeal does not compensate for the defendant's failure to present any proofs of a substantial and meaningful change in the value of the subject property resulting from the alterations. <end>

Dep’t of Veterans Affairs, 498 U.S. 89, 96, 111 S.Ct. 453, 457-58, 112 L.Ed.2d 435 (1990) (explaining that equitable tolling generally cannot be invoked if “the claimant failed to exercise due diligence in preserving his legal rights”); Motta, 717 F.3d at 846-47 (<HOLDING>). According to the rule established in the case of Irwin v. Dep't of Veterans Affairs, a plaintiff is not reasonably diligent when she fails to investigate basic issues relevant to her claim or proceed with it promptly. This lack of diligence may have an impact on Ms. Wilson's ability to recover the benefits she claimed. <end>

In keeping with the importance of this rule, if a sentencing court fails to provide a defendant with the chance to address the court, the reviewing court must remand the case for resentencing, generally without needing to inquire into prejudice. See De Alba Pagan, 33 F.3d at 130. To satisfy the requirements of Rule 32(c)(3)(C), we encourage the sentencing court to address the defendant personally, see Green, 365 U.S. at 304, 81 S.Ct. 653, and allow the defendant to speak on all topics which the defendant considers relevant. See De Alba Pagan, 33 F.3d at 129. The sentencing judge must be explicit when informing the defendant of her right to allocute. See United States v. Edgecomb, 910 F.2d 1309, 1315 (6th Cir. 1990) (<HOLDING>); see also United States v. Navarro-Flores, 628 <question> What is the importance of allowing a defendant to address the court during the sentencing process? <issues> Importance of defendant allocution during the sentencing process <rules> Rule 32(c)(3)(C) <analysis> The importance of allowing a defendant to address the court during the sentencing process is rooted in the principles of fairness and due process. The right to allocute provides the defendant an opportunity to personally express their thoughts, feelings, and remorse to the court before a final sentence is imposed. It allows the defendant to humanize themselves and provide context or mitigating factors that could potentially influence the judge's decision. By giving the defendant a voice in the sentencing process, it helps ensure that their individual circumstances and perspective are taken into consideration, promoting a fair and just outcome. <answer> The importance of allowing a defendant to address the court during the sentencing process is rooted in the principles of fairness and due process. It provides the defendant with the opportunity to personally express their thoughts, feelings, and remorse to the court before a final sentence is imposed. This right, known as allocution, allows the defendant to humanize themselves and provide context or mitigating factors that could potentially influence the judge's decision. By giving the defendant a voice in the sentencing process, it helps ensure that their individual circumstances and perspective are taken into consideration, promoting a fair and just outcome. Failure to provide this opportunity may result in a case being remanded for resentencing. <end>

<context> losses ... without consideration of the economic circumstances of the defendant.” 18 U.S.C. § 3663A(f)(l)(A). At this first stage, the district court lacks “any discretion to contemplate the defendant’s financial situation.” United States v. Jones, 289 F.3d 1260, 1265 (11th Cir. 2002). Second, after the district court establishes the total amount of restitution owed, the district court considers the defendant’s financial resources to create a schedule for restitution payments. 18 U.S.C. § 3663A(f)(2). At this second stage, the court should consider the defendant’s finances. Jones, 289 F.3d 1260, 1265 (11th Cir. 2002). Second, after establishing the total amount of restitution owed, the court considers the defendant's financial resources to create a schedule for restitution payments, as per 18 U.S.C. § 3663A(f)(2). Jones, 289 F.3d 1260, 1265 (11th Cir. 2002). However, after establishing the total amount of restitution owed, the court considers the defendant's financial resources to create a payment schedule, as per 18 U.S.C. § 3663A(f)(2). The defendant has the burden of demonstrating their financial condition, and the court can rely on the probation report without making independent findings, as mentioned in United States v. Jones, 289 F.3d at 1266. <end>

The limited duty rule is an exception to general negligence principles, and more particularly, to the application of the business invitee standard of care in the commercial context. The dissent apparently prefers not to consider public policy and fairness concepts if the result is to hold the owner of the commercial enterprise responsible for its negligence when it does not adequately protect its business invitees, at least outside of the spectator seating areas. But, the Court is required by its common law precedents to examine the owner’s duty in those circumstances, and to consider which of the parties is best able to bear the burden of foreseeable harm within the stadium. See Carter Lincoln-Mercury, Inc. v. It determines the extent of a property owner's duty to protect business invitees from harm. <analysis> The limited duty rule is applied when assessing the owner's duty of care in a commercial setting. It recognizes that the standard of care owed to business invitees may differ from the general negligence principles. The dissent in this case appears to favor not considering public policy and fairness concepts when holding the owner of a commercial enterprise responsible for negligence. However, the court is obligated to examine the owner's duty based on common law precedents and determine which party is best able to bear the burden of foreseeable harm within the stadium. <answer> The limited duty rule is an exception to general negligence principles in the commercial context. It specifically relates to the application of the business invitee standard of care. In this case, the court is required to examine the owner's duty and determine which party should bear the burden of foreseeable harm within the stadium. The dissent's position seems to disregard public policy and fairness concepts in holding the owner responsible for negligence. However, the court is obligated to consider common law precedents in making its decision. <end>

If the moving party meets this burden, the burden then shifts to the non-moving party to present evidence that creates a genuine issue of material fact. Ultimately, the court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party and determine whether there is a genuine issue of material fact that would warrant a trial. <end>

Without evidence of coercion, a motion to suppress the confessions cannot succeed. <end>

Doctrine of Necessary Implication To begin, we note that “narrow construction is the rule in determining the scope of the condemnation power delegated pursuant to legislative enactment.” Coquina Oil Corp. v. Harry Kourlis Ranch, 643 P.2d 519, 522 (Colo.1982) (finding that a federal oil and gas lessee could not condemn private property for private use as a right-of-way based on a condemnation statute which was silent as to whether federal oil and gas lessees could exercise the power granted therein). Because we construe the statute against the entity asserting the authority, we will not find an implied grant of the condemnation authority through “vague or doubtful language.” Beth Medrosh Hagodol v. City of Aurora, 126 Colo. 267, 272, 248 P.2d 732, 735 (1952) (<HOLDING>); see also, e.g., Mack v. Town of Craig, 68 <question> What is the doctrine of necessary implication? <issues> Understanding the doctrine of necessary implication <rules> The rule of narrow construction in determining the scope of the condemnation power delegated pursuant to legislative enactment <analysis> The doctrine of necessary implication holds that when interpreting a condemnation statute, the courts will construe it narrowly against the entity asserting the condemnation authority. This means that the power to condemn private property for private use cannot be implied unless the statute clearly grants such authority. The courts will not find an implied grant of condemnation authority through vague or doubtful language. <answer> The doctrine of necessary implication is a principle in interpreting condemnation statutes. It states that the courts will construe such statutes narrowly against the entity asserting the condemnation authority. This means that unless the statute clearly grants the authority to condemn private property for private use, it cannot be implied. The courts will not find an implied grant of condemnation authority through vague or doubtful language. <end>

<context> under 18 U.S.C. § 2314. His contention is that Palmyra Island is not a possession of the United States within the meaning of the relevant statutes. We disagree and affirm the district court’s denial of his petition. One of the elements of 18 U.S.C. § 2314 is that the stolen property was transported in “interstate commerce.” 18 U.S.C. § 10 defines “interstate commerce” as “commerce between one State, Territory, Possession, or the District of Columbia and another State, Territory, Possession, or the District of Columbia.” Palmyra Island is a possession of the United States. See 48 U.S.C. § 644a (placing Palmyra and seven other American Pacific Islands under the jurisdiction of the District of Hawaii); United States v.
