<context> of section 833(a) is not intended to foreclose a spouse's ability to challenge the legitimacy of a child. If such were the case, then the presumption of section 833(a) becomes a substantive rule of law, and not a presumption. See 5 V.I.C. § 812 (distinguishing between the evidentiary effects of a "presumption," and a "conclusive or irrefutable presumption"). As a presumption is inherently rebuttable, section 833(a) offers three procedural devices for rebutting the presumption of legitimacy. One such device is a "court action." In a court action or proceeding, the spouse challenging the legitimacy of a child born during a marriage is saddled with the burden of proof, requiring the challenging spouse to posit competent evidence in support of his or her claim. See Phaire, 17 V.I. at 242 (<HOLDING>). The types of evidence available to rebut the <question> What is the burden of proof for a spouse challenging the legitimacy of a child born during a marriage? <issues> Burden of proof for challenging the legitimacy of a child <rules> Section 833(a) provides three procedural devices for rebutting the presumption of legitimacy <analysis> In a court action or proceeding, the spouse challenging the legitimacy of a child born during a marriage is saddled with the burden of proof, requiring the challenging spouse to posit competent evidence in support of his or her claim. <answer> The burden of proof for a spouse challenging the legitimacy of a child born during a marriage is on the challenging spouse. In a court action or proceeding, the challenging spouse must present competent evidence in support of their claim to rebut the presumption of legitimacy provided by section 833(a). <end>

See also Shiek, 2002 ND 85, ¶ 15, 643 N.W.2d 721 (noting the definition of disability is broader than lost wages, it means loss of earning capacity); Business Ins. Co. v. Labor and Industry Review Comm’n, 159 <question> What is the difference between actual earnings and earning capacity in the context of workers' compensation? <issues> Difference between actual earnings and earning capacity <rules> Comparing actual earnings before the injury with earning capacity after the injury <analysis> Actual earnings are a relatively concrete quantity, while earning capacity is a more theoretical concept. In light of these definitions, defendants’ attempt to characterize the program at Jewel Manor as “treatment,” rather than “education,” must fail. <context> was evidence of contrary intent. The lien, once executed, remained in force during the life of the debt. Id. (citing Ploeger v. Johnson, 26 S.W. 432 (Tex.Civ.App.—Dallas 1894, no writ) and cases ff.) A mere renewal did not affect the lien. However, a renewal could amount to a novation. If, for sufficient consideration, the parties executed a renewal intending a satisfaction of the old debt or lien, it had that effect and the rights of the parties were governed by the new contract. Id. (citing Helmke v. Uecker, 161 S.W. 17 (Tex.Civ.App.—Austin 1913, no writ). While the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals has not spoken to this precise question, it has been squarely addressed and answered by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals in Mat , supra); In re Wandler, 77 B.R. 735 (Bankr.D.N.D.1987) (<HOLDING>); In re Challinor, 79 B.R. 19 <question> What effect does a renewal have on a lien? <issues> Effect of renewal on lien <rules> A renewal may amount to a novation <analysis> If the parties execute a renewal intending to satisfy the old debt or lien, it has the effect of a novation and the rights of the parties are governed by the new contract. <answer> A renewal of a lien may amount to a novation. If the parties execute a renewal with the intention to satisfy the old debt or lien, it has the effect of a novation and the rights of the parties will be governed by the new contract. <end>

The better course, obviously, is to provide the photo array or other evidence of the prior identification immediately, while the declarant is still on the witness stand. But events at trial sometimes make the better course impractical. In such circumstances, a meaningful opportunity to cross-examine a declarant regarding his prior identification is enough to satisfy the requirements of Rule 801, even if the defendant chooses not to use the opportunity. See United States v. Elemy, 656 F.2d 507, 508 (9th Cir.1981) (<HOLDING>). It is preferable to present the photo array or other evidence of the prior identification immediately while the witness is still on the stand, but this may not always be feasible. <end>

<context> need not have the specific intent to intimidate. See Mot. to Dismiss Counts 3 & 5, at 8-9. Although bank robbery does not require the specific intent to intimidate, it does require general intent—a defendant must know that he is taking a bank’s property by force and violence or intimidation. Carter v. United States, 530 U.S. 255, 268, 120 S.Ct. 2159, 147 L.Ed.2d 203 (2000). A “knowing or intentional application of force is a “use” of force.” United States v. Castleman, — U.S. -, 134 S.Ct. 1405, 1415, 188 L.Ed.2d 426 (2014) (emphasis added). Because bank robbery requires either the knowing use of “force and violence” or a knowing threat of force, it is a crime of violence under the elements clause of Section 924(c). See United States v. McNeal, 818 F.3d 141, 155 (4th Cir. 2016) (<HOLDING>). Second, the additional element of armed bank <question> What elements are required for bank robbery to be considered a crime of violence? <issues> Determining the elements required for bank robbery to be considered a crime of violence. <rules> Bank robbery requires either the knowing use of 'force and violence' or a knowing threat of force. <analysis> Bank robbery meets the definition of a crime of violence under the elements clause of Section 924(c) because it requires either the knowing use of force or a knowing threat of force. <answer> In order for bank robbery to be considered a crime of violence, it must involve either the knowing use of force and violence or a knowing threat of force. This requirement is based on the interpretation of the elements clause of Section 924(c). The use of force can include both physical force and intimidation. Therefore, if a defendant knows that they are taking a bank's property by force and violence or intimidation, it meets the general intent requirement for bank robbery. As established in Carter v. United States, 530 U.S. 255, 268, 120 S.Ct. 2159, 147 L.Ed.2d 203 (2000), the specific intent to intimidate is not necessary for bank robbery. Additionally, United States v. Castleman clarified that a knowing or intentional application of force is considered a 'use' of force. Taking all these factors into account, bank robbery is classified as a crime of violence under the elements clause of Section 924(c). <end>

<context> to determine the defendant's competence to waive the right to counsel). Specifically, a defendant is competent to waive the right to counsel if he has "sufficient present ability to consult with his lawyer with a reasonable degree of rational understanding{[ ] and ... has a rational as well as factual understanding of the proceedings against him." Dusky, 362 U.S. at 402, 80 S.Ct. 788. 117 If a trial court finds that a defendant fails to meet this standard, then the defendant may not waive the right to counsel. See Godinez, 509 U.S. at 399, 118 S.Ct. 2680. If the defendant satisfies the Dusky competency standard, however, he may waive the right to counsel if his waiver is voluntary, knowing, and intelligent. Arguello, 772 P.2d at 94; see also Faretta, 422 U.S. at 807, 95 S.Ct. 2525 (<HOLDING>). 118 A "voluntary" waiver, like any voluntary <question> Under what circumstances can a defendant waive the right to counsel? <issues> Determining the circumstances under which a defendant can waive the right to counsel. <rules> A defendant is competent to waive the right to counsel if they have sufficient present ability to consult with a lawyer with a reasonable degree of rational understanding and have a rational as well as factual understanding of the proceedings against them. If a trial court finds that a defendant fails to meet this standard, they may not waive the right to counsel. However, if the defendant satisfies the Dusky competency standard and their waiver is voluntary, knowing, and intelligent, they may waive the right to counsel. <analysis> To determine the circumstances under which a defendant can waive the right to counsel, the court must assess the defendant's competence. The court will evaluate whether the defendant has the ability to consult with a lawyer and understand the proceedings against them. If the defendant fails to meet this standard, they cannot waive the right to counsel. If the defendant meets the competency standard and their waiver is voluntary, knowing, and intelligent, they can waive the right to counsel. <answer> A defendant can waive the right to counsel under the following circumstances: (1) they have sufficient present ability to consult with a lawyer with a reasonable degree of rational understanding, and (2) they have a rational as well as factual understanding of the proceedings against them. However, if a trial court finds that a defendant fails to meet this standard, they may not waive the right to counsel. If the defendant satisfies the Dusky competency standard and their waiver is voluntary, knowing, and intelligent, they may waive the right to counsel. <end>

Such an interpretation would undermine the core purpose of both the D’Oench doctrine and its statutory cousins, i.e., allowing the FDIC to make its necessary decisions and evaluations, which sometimes must be made with lightning speed, by relying on the written bank records. For the foregoing reasons, we therefore hold that neither FIRREA, nor the Federal Deposit Insurance Act of 1950, preempted the federal common law D’Oench doctrine. B. Can Motorcity Avoid the D’Oench Doctrine if it Repaid its Loans to Southeast Prior to B Cir.1995) (<HOLDING>); John v. RTC, 39 F.3d 773, 776-77 (7th <question> Can Motorcity avoid the D’Oench Doctrine if it repaid its loans to Southeast prior to B Cir.1995? <issues> The issue is whether Motorcity can avoid the D’Oench Doctrine by repaying its loans to Southeast prior to B Cir.1995. <rules> The D’Oench Doctrine is a federal common law doctrine that prohibits a party from relying on oral agreements or side agreements that are not reflected in the written bank records when dealing with federal banking agencies. The doctrine applies to cases where a party attempts to escape liability by asserting an oral agreement that is in direct contradiction to the written bank records. Furthermore, the doctrine is meant to protect the FDIC and other federal banking agencies from being deceived or unable to make necessary decisions based on accurate and reliable bank records. <analysis> Motorcity's interpretation seeks to take advantage of oral agreements and evade the D’Oench Doctrine by arguing that repaying the loans to Southeast prior to B Cir.1995 should exempt them from the doctrine. However, such an interpretation would undermine the core purpose of the D’Oench doctrine and its statutory cousins, which is to allow the FDIC to rely on written bank records when making necessary decisions and evaluations. The repayment of loans does not nullify the applicability of the D’Oench Doctrine, as the doctrine is concerned with protecting federal banking agencies from being deceived or unable to rely on written bank records. <answer> Motorcity cannot avoid the D’Oench Doctrine by repaying its loans to Southeast prior to B Cir.1995. The D’Oench Doctrine is a federal common law doctrine that prohibits parties from relying on oral agreements that are not reflected in the written bank records. The doctrine is designed to protect federal banking agencies, such as the FDIC, from being deceived or unable to make necessary decisions based on accurate and reliable bank records. Repaying the loans does not exempt Motorcity from the application of the D’Oench Doctrine, as the doctrine's purpose is to ensure the integrity and reliance on written bank records for decision-making. <end>

<context> 42 of the United States Code is a federal statute which “provides a civil remedy against any ‘person’ who, under color of state law, subjects a ‘citizen of the United States’ to the ‘deprivation of any rights, privileges, or immunities’ secured by the federal Constitution or federal laws.” Bayh v. Sonnenburg, 573 N.E.2d 398, 402 (Ind.1991) (quoting 42 U.S.C. § 1983). “By the plain terms of § 1983, two — and only two — allegations are required in order to state a cause of action under that statute.” Gomez v. Toledo, 446 U.S. 635, 640, 100 S.Ct. 1920, 64 L.Ed.2d 572 (1980). A § 1983 claim need only allege that “some person has deprived [the claimant] of a federal right” and that person “acted under color of state or territorial-law.” Id. Toledo, two allegations are required to state a cause of action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983: (1) that the claimant has been deprived of a federal right, and (2) that the person responsible acted under color of state or territorial law. <analysis> To state a cause of action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, a claimant must allege that they have been deprived of a federal right and that the person responsible acted under color of state or territorial law. This requirement is based on the ruling in Gomez v. Toledo, where the Supreme Court stated that only these two allegations are necessary to state a cause of action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. <answer> To state a cause of action under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, two allegations are required: (1) the claimant must allege that they have been deprived of a federal right, and (2) the person responsible must have acted under color of state or territorial law. LAW The statutes authorizing the Sentencing Guidelines require judges to consider “the need for the sentence imposed ... to reflect the seriousness of the offense [and] to promote respect for the law.” 18 U.S.C. § 3553(a)(2). Both of these goals require consideration of the harm caused by the defendant. 1) Seriousness of the offense In Payne v. Tennessee, 501 U.S. 808, 111 S.Ct. 2597, 115 L.Ed.2d 720 (1991), the Supreme Court held that evidence of victim impact is relevant to the seriousness of the offense, and, therefore, to the appropriate sentence. The Court explicitly overruled two prior decisions — South Carolina v. Gathers, 490 U.S. 805, 109 S.Ct. 2207, 104 L.Ed.2d 876 (1989), and Booth v. Maryland, 482 U.S. 496, 107 S.Ct. 2529, 96 L.Ed.2d 440 (1987) (<HOLDING>) 501 U.S. at 817, 825, 111 S.Ct. at 2604, 2608. <question> What is the relevance of victim impact evidence in determining the seriousness of an offense? <issues> The relevance of victim impact evidence in determining the seriousness of an offense <rules> The Supreme Court's decision in Payne v. Tennessee <analysis> In the case of Payne v. Tennessee, the Supreme Court held that evidence of victim impact is relevant to the seriousness of the offense, and therefore, to the appropriate sentence. This decision overruled two prior decisions, namely South Carolina v. Gathers and Booth v. Maryland. The Court recognized that considering the harm caused by the defendant is necessary to reflect the seriousness of the offense and to promote respect for the law. By allowing the introduction of victim impact evidence in sentencing, the Court acknowledged the importance of considering the consequences of the offense on the victims and their families in determining the appropriate punishment. <answer> Victim impact evidence is relevant in determining the seriousness of an offense. This was established in the Supreme Court case of Payne v. Tennessee, where it was held that evidence of victim impact is relevant to the appropriate sentence. The Court recognized the importance of considering the harm caused by the defendant in reflecting the seriousness of the offense and promoting respect for the law. This decision overruled two prior decisions and allowed for the introduction of victim impact evidence in sentencing, emphasizing the need to consider the consequences of the offense on the victims and their families when determining the appropriate punishment. <end>

The court held that such conclusory allegations are insufficient to state a claim. <end>

Cronic case, counsel's representation might be presumed to have occurred even without a showing of prejudice. <end>

Authority To Bind The United States Even if the court were to assume arguen-do that Kozak has demonstrated the existence of a cooperation agreement between her and Iowa authorities, Kozak must also demonstrate that the state cooperation agreement is binding on the United States. Federal circuit courts of appeal have held that agreements made by state agents cannot be enforced against the United States because state agents are without authority to bind federal proceedings. Hendrix v. Norris, 81 F.3d 805, 807 (8th Cir.1996) (“ ‘[S]tate prosecutors cannot bind federal prosecutors without the latter’s knowledge and consent.’ ”) (quoting United States v. Fuzer, 18 F.3d 517, 520 (7th Cir.1994)); United States v. Sparks, 87 F.3d 276, 279 (9th Cir.1996) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Cordova-Perez, 65 F.3d 1552, <question> Can agreements made by state agents be enforced against the United States? <issues> The issue is whether agreements made by state agents can be enforced against the United States. <rules> According to federal circuit courts of appeal, agreements made by state agents cannot be enforced against the United States. <analysis> The courts have held that state agents are without authority to bind federal proceedings, and therefore, agreements made by state agents cannot bind federal prosecutors without their knowledge and consent. <answer> No, agreements made by state agents cannot be enforced against the United States as per the rulings of federal circuit courts of appeal. State agents are without authority to bind federal proceedings, and federal prosecutors cannot be bound by agreements made by state prosecutors without their knowledge and consent. <end>

A party may waive its right to arbitration by expressly indicating that it wishes to resolve its claims in court. Gilmore v. Shearson/Amer. Express Inc., 811 F.2d 108, 112 (2d Cir.1987), overruling on other grounds recognized by McDonnell Douglas Fin. Corp. v. Pa. Power & Light Co., 849 F.2d 761, 763-64 (2d Cir.1988). Alternately, a party may impliedly waive its right to enforce a contractual arbitration clause when it “engages in protracted litigation that results in prejudice to the opposing party.” S & R Co. of Kingston v. Latona Trucking, 159 F.3d 80, 83 (2d Cir.1998) (citations omitted); Manos v. Additionally, a party may impliedly waive its right to enforce a contractual arbitration clause when it engages in protracted litigation that results in prejudice to the opposing party. <analysis> Under the Gilmore v. Shearson/Amer. Express Inc. case, a party can waive its right to arbitration by expressly indicating its intention to resolve its claims in court. This means that if a party explicitly states that it wants to go to court instead of arbitration, it will have waived its right to arbitration. Moreover, the S & R Co. of Kingston v. Latona Trucking case states that a party can also impliedly waive its right to arbitration if it engages in protracted litigation that results in prejudice to the opposing party. In such cases, the party's actions of engaging in lengthy litigation instead of invoking the arbitration clause can be considered as a waiver of their right to arbitration. <answer> A party may waive its right to arbitration by expressly indicating that it wishes to resolve its claims in court. This can be done by explicitly stating the intention to go to court instead of arbitration. Additionally, a party may impliedly waive its right to enforce a contractual arbitration clause when it engages in protracted litigation that results in prejudice to the opposing party. In such cases, by engaging in extensive litigation instead of invoking the arbitration clause, the party can be considered to have waived their right to arbitration. <end>

A recent Ninth Circuit ruling relying largely on the dissenting opinion in Winter parsed the language of Winter and subsequent Ninth Circuit rulings and determined that the sliding scale test remains viable when there is a lesser showing of likelihood of success on the merits amounting to “serious questions,” but not when there is a lesser showing of likelihood of irreparable harm. See Alliance for the Wild Rockies v. Cottrell, 622 F.3d 1045, 1052-53 (9th Cir.2010). This case presents some difficulty in light of Winter and prior Ninth Circuit cases. To the extent Cottrell’s interpretation of Winter is inconsistent with Selecky, Selecky controls. Miller v. Gammie, 335 F.3d 889, 899 (9th Cir.2003) (en banc) (<HOLDING>). In any case, the Supreme Court stated in <question> What is the sliding scale test and when does it remain viable? <issues> Understanding the concept of the sliding scale test and its viability <rules> The ruling in Alliance for the Wild Rockies v. Cottrell stating that the sliding scale test remains viable when there is a lesser showing of likelihood of success on the merits amounting to 'serious questions,' but not when there is a lesser showing of likelihood of irreparable harm. <analysis> The court ruling in Alliance for the Wild Rockies v. Cottrell clarifies that the sliding scale test remains viable when there is a lesser showing of likelihood of success on the merits amounting to 'serious questions,' which means that a party can still obtain preliminary injunctive relief even if they do not show a high likelihood of success, as long as there are serious questions to be decided. However, the sliding scale test does not remain viable when there is a lesser showing of likelihood of irreparable harm, indicating that irreparable harm must be shown to obtain preliminary injunctive relief. <answer> The sliding scale test refers to a standard used in determining whether to grant preliminary injunctive relief. According to the ruling in Alliance for the Wild Rockies v. Cottrell, the sliding scale test remains viable when there is a lesser showing of likelihood of success on the merits amounting to 'serious questions,' but not when there is a lesser showing of likelihood of irreparable harm. This means that a party can still obtain preliminary injunctive relief even if they do not show a high likelihood of success, as long as there are serious questions to be decided. However, to obtain preliminary injunctive relief, it is necessary to demonstrate a likelihood of irreparable harm. Our legislature established restitution as part of a defendant’s sentence. “A victim of a crime has the right to receive restitution as part of the disposition of a criminal charge ... against the offender if. the offender is' convicted.” Minn.Stat, § 611A.04, subd. 1(a) (2012). And Minn. Stat. § 609.10, subd. 1(a)(5) (2012), provides that court-ordered restitution is a sentence that may be imposed upon conviction of a felony. Minnesota courts have consistently interpreted these statutes to mean that restitution is part of a criminal sentence. See Evans v. Furthermore, Minn. Stat. § 609.10, subd. 1(a)(5) (2012) states that court-ordered restitution is a sentence that may be imposed upon conviction of a felony. <context> inquiring whether Congress has spoken to the precise question at issue. Clearly it has not. The Immigration and Nationality Act, 8 U.S.C. § 1101 et seq. (“INA”), does not define the term “spouse,” nor does it dictate criteria for the USCIS to use in examining the validity of a marriage. Thus, USCIS has had to interpret the ambiguous terms of the INA to determine what choice of law rule to apply when determining the validity of a marriage for immigration purposes. Turning to the second step of the Chevron analysis, the Court finds that US-CIS’s interpretation of the INA is reasonable. In determining whether a marriage is valid for immigration purposes, USCIS applies the laws of the place where the marriage was celebrated. See, e.g., Matter of Hosseinian, 19 I. & N. Moored, 38 F.3d 1419, 1422 (6th Cir.1994) (internal quotation marks and citation omitted, emphasis added). Accordingly, when no express lim t court violated § 3553(c) when it failed to explain the reasons underlying his sentence “in open court.” Indeed, the Second Circuit has held that upon resentencing, the reasons supporting the sentence must be pronounced by the district court from the bench. See DeMott, 513 F.3d at 58 (<HOLDING>). We agree and hold that upon general remand, <question> What specific limitations are there in an appellate court's mandate when vacating a sentence and remanding the case for re-sentencing? <issues> Limitations in an appellate court's mandate when vacating a sentence and remanding the case for re-sentencing <rules> An order vacating a sentence and remanding the case for re-sentencing directs the sentencing court to begin anew <analysis> When no express limitations are stated in the appellate court's mandate, the sentencing court has the authority to conduct a fully de novo resentencing <answer> When an appellate court vacates a sentence and remands the case for re-sentencing, the sentencing court is directed to start the sentencing process again without any restrictions unless explicitly mentioned in the appellate court's mandate. This means the sentencing court has the authority to conduct a fully de novo resentencing, allowing for a complete reevaluation of the sentence. In the absence of any limitations stated in the mandate, the sentencing court has the discretion to consider all relevant factors and make a new sentencing decision. <end>

<context> that did not satisfy the machine-or-transformation test were rarely granted in earlier eras, especially in the Industrial Age, as explained by Judge Dyk’s thoughtful historical review. See 545 F.3d, at 966-976 (concurring opinion). But times change. Technology and other innovations progress in unexpected ways. For example, it was once forcefully argued that until recent times, “well-established principles of patent law probably would have prevented the issuance of a valid patent on almost any conceivable computer program.” Diehr, 450 U.S., at 195, 101 S. Ct. 1048, 67 L. Ed. 2d 155 (Stevens, J., dissenting). But this fact does not mean that unforeseen innovations such as computer programs are always unpatentable. See id., at 192-193, 101 S. Ct. 1048, 67 L. Ed. 2d 155 (majority opinion) (<HOLDING>). Section 101 is a “dynamic provision designed <question> Are unforeseen innovations such as computer programs always unpatentable? <issues> Determining the patentability of unforeseen innovations such as computer programs <rules> Section 101 of patent law, historical review by Judge Dyk <analysis> In the past, innovations that did not satisfy the machine-or-transformation test were rarely granted patents. However, times have changed and technology and innovations progress in unexpected ways. However, this does not mean that unforeseen innovations such as computer programs are always unpatentable. <answer> No, unforeseen innovations such as computer programs are not always unpatentable. In the past, the machine-or-transformation test was used to determine patentability, and innovations that did not satisfy this test were rarely granted patents. However, with the advancement of technology and unexpected progress in innovation, the landscape has changed. Although it was previously argued that patent law principles would have prevented the issuance of valid patents for computer programs, this does not mean that all computer programs are unpatentable. Section 101 of patent law is a dynamic provision designed to accommodate unforeseen innovations. <end>

<context> relationship” exception is drawn from Restatement § 315, which provides: “There is no duty so to control the conduct of a third person as to prevent him from causing physical harm to another unless “(a) a special relation exists between the actor and the third person which imposes a duty upon the actor to control the third person’s conduct, or “(b) a special relation exists between the actor and the other which gives to the other a right to protection.” (Emphasis added.) The relationship between Ms. Patterson (the “actor”) and Marquette (the “third person”) was that of grandmother and adult grandson. This familial relationship imposed no duty on the elderly Ms. Patterson to control Marquette. See, e.g., Bell & Hudson, P.C. v. Buhl Realty Co., 185 Mich.App. 714, 462 N.W.2d 851 (1990) (<HOLDING>). The relationship between Ms. Patterson (the <question> Based on the relationship between Ms. Patterson and Marquette, was Ms. Patterson obligated to control Marquette's conduct to prevent physical harm to another? <issues> Whether a special relationship existed between Ms. Patterson and Marquette that imposed a duty upon Ms. Patterson to control Marquette's conduct. <rules> According to Restatement § 315, there is no duty to control the conduct of a third person to prevent physical harm unless a special relationship exists between the actor and the third person that imposes a duty for control, or a special relationship exists between the actor and the other party that gives the other a right to protection. <analysis> In this case, the relationship between Ms. Patterson (the actor) and Marquette (the third person) was that of grandmother and adult grandson. However, the familial relationship alone does not impose a duty on Ms. Patterson to control Marquette. Therefore, Ms. Patterson was not obligated to control Marquette's conduct to prevent physical harm to another. <answer> No, Ms. Patterson was not obligated to control Marquette's conduct to prevent physical harm to another based on the lack of a special relationship between them that imposed such a duty. <end>

<context> (“The most adequate plaintiff shall, subject to the approval of the court, select and retain counsel to represent the class.”). Courts typically do not disturb a lead plaintiffs choice of counsel unless doing so is necessary to protect the interests of the class. See Cavanaugh, 306 F.3d 726, 733 (9th Cir.2002) (“[T]he district court must approve the lead plaintiffs choice of counsel, but Congress gave the lead plaintiff, and not the court, the power to select a lawyer for the class.”). The presumption that a lead plaintiff fulfills the typicality and adequacy requirements can be rebutted by a showing that the plaintiff is in fact not adequate or will be subject to unique defenses. See, e.g., See In re Network Assoc., Inc. Sec. Litig., 76 F.Supp.2d 1017, 1029 (N.D.Cal.1999) (<HOLDING>). 1. The Pension Fund Group The Pension Fund <question> What specific requirements must be met in order for a lead plaintiff to select and retain counsel to represent a class? <issues> Requirements for lead plaintiff to select and retain counsel <rules> The most adequate plaintiff shall select and retain counsel to represent the class, subject to court approval. The lead plaintiff has the power to choose a lawyer for the class. <analysis> According to the passage, in order for a lead plaintiff to select and retain counsel to represent a class, the plaintiff must be the most adequate, and the selection must be subject to court approval. Congress has given the lead plaintiff the authority to choose a lawyer for the class. The court typically does not disturb the lead plaintiff's choice of counsel unless it is necessary to protect the interests of the class. <answer> To select and retain counsel to represent a class, the lead plaintiff must meet the requirement of being the most adequate plaintiff. The selection of counsel is subject to the approval of the court. The lead plaintiff has the power to choose a lawyer for the class, as granted by Congress. Courts typically do not interfere with the lead plaintiff's choice of counsel unless it is necessary to protect the interests of the class. <end>

<context> that he told the same story before the motive or influence came into existence or before the time of the alleged recent fabrication. [In those circumstances], the prior consistent statement is defined as not hearsay . . . and thus is admitted into evidence. Unless a witness’s veracity has affirmatively been placed in issue, the witness’s prior consistent statement is pure hearsay evidence, which cannot be admitted merely to corroborate the witness, or to bolster the witness’s credibility in the eyes of the jury. Woodard, 269 Ga. at 320 (footnotes omitted; emphasis in original). Put another way, “to be admissible to refute the allegation of recent fabrication, improper influence, or improper motive, the prior statement must‘predate the alleged fabrication, in 05 SE2d 649) (2011) (<HOLDING>); Duggan, 285 Ga. at 366 (holding that <question> What is the definition of a prior consistent statement and when is it admissible in court? <issues> Definition and admissibility of prior consistent statements <rules> Prior consistent statement is defined as not hearsay and admissible into evidence if it predates the alleged fabrication, improper influence, or improper motive; Witness's veracity must be affirmatively placed in issue for admission of prior consistent statement <analysis> A prior consistent statement is a statement made by a witness that is consistent with the witness's testimony in court. It is considered not hearsay and is admissible into evidence if it predates the alleged fabrication, improper influence, or improper motive. However, the witness's veracity or credibility must be affirmatively placed in issue, meaning there must be some doubt raised about the witness's truthfulness or accuracy, for the prior consistent statement to be admitted. <answer> A prior consistent statement is a statement made by a witness that is consistent with their testimony in court. It is defined as not hearsay and is admissible into evidence if it predates the alleged fabrication, improper influence, or improper motive. However, the admission of a prior consistent statement is subject to the condition that the witness's veracity or credibility has been affirmatively placed in issue. In other words, there must be some doubt raised about the witness's truthfulness or accuracy for the prior consistent statement to be admitted as evidence. <end>

<context> into evidence true and accurate copies of the Note and Allonge. Petitioner asserts this evidence “plainly evidences the transfers” of the Note to Petitioner. We cannot agree. Under the UCC, as adopted by North Carolina, “[a]n instrument is transferred when it is delivered by a person other than its issuer for the purpose of giving to the person receiving delivery the right to enforce the instrument.” N.C. Gen. Stat. § 25-3-203(a) (2009). Production of an original note at trial does not, in itself, establish that the note was transferred to the party presenting the note with the purpose of giving that party the right to enforce the instrument, as demonstrated in Connolly, 63 N.C. App. at 551, 306 S.E.2d at 125, and Smathers v. Smathers, 34 N.C. App. 724, 726, 239 S.E.2d 637, 638 (1977) (<HOLDING>) In Connolly, determining who had possession of <question> Under what conditions is an instrument considered transferred under the UCC as adopted by North Carolina? <issues> Definition of transfer of an instrument under the UCC in North Carolina <rules> An instrument is transferred when it is delivered by a person other than its issuer for the purpose of giving to the person receiving delivery the right to enforce the instrument. [N.C. Gen. This means that in order for an instrument to be considered transferred, it must be delivered to someone other than the issuer, and the delivery must be made with the intention of giving the recipient the right to enforce the instrument. <end>

The authority to sell Philadelphia insurance, subject to Philadelphia’s ultimate approval, would not also impliedly include the ability of Wortham to accept notice of a claim on Philadelphia’s policy several years after Wortham had completed the brokering transaction. The distinction between handling and procurement is supported by case law. <answer> No, Wortham does not have the authority to accept notice of a claim on Philadelphia's policy. <context> Care Servs. v. Dobos, 380 So.2d 516, 518 (Fla.Dist.Ct.App.1980) (referring to rule as the “officious intermeddler doctrine”). In certain circumstances, however, restitution for services performed will be required even though the recipient did not request or voluntarily consent to receive such services. For example, section 116 of the Restatement of Restitution provides: A person who has supplied things or services to another, although acting without the other’s knowledge or consent, is entitled to restitution therefor from the other if (a) he acted unofficiously and with intent to charge therefor, and (b) the things or services were necessary to prevent the other from suffering serious bodily harm or pain, and (c) the person supplying them had no reason to know that 668, 675 (1996) (<HOLDING>). 2. Application of law to facts. The district <question> When is restitution for services performed required even without the recipient's request or consent? <issues> Determining when restitution for services performed is required without the recipient's request or consent. <rules> Section 116 of the Restatement of Restitution provides that a person who has supplied things or services to another, although acting without the other's knowledge or consent, is entitled to restitution therefor if (a) he acted unofficiously and with intent to charge therefor, (b) the things or services were necessary to prevent the other from suffering serious bodily harm or pain, and (c) the person supplying them had no reason to know. <analysis> In certain circumstances, restitution for services performed will be required even though the recipient did not request or voluntarily consent to receive such services. This is based on the criteria set forth in section 116 of the Restatement of Restitution, which requires the person supplying the services to have acted unofficiously, with intent to charge for the services, and with no reason to know that the recipient would not want or need them. Additionally, the services must have been necessary to prevent the recipient from suffering serious bodily harm or pain. <answer> Restitution for services performed is required even without the recipient's request or consent if certain conditions are met. According to section 116 of the Restatement of Restitution, the person supplying the services must have acted unofficiously, with intent to charge for the services, and without reason to know that the recipient would not want or need them. Furthermore, the services must have been necessary to prevent the recipient from suffering serious bodily harm or pain. If these criteria are satisfied, the person supplying the services is entitled to restitution from the recipient. <end>

Although such a mistake is not automatically reversible per se, the court held that it undermined the fairness of the trial in this particular case. <end>

Linter Group Ltd., 994 F.2d 996, 1001 (2d Cir.1993) (“[T]here is ... a strong presumption in favor of a plaintiffs choice of forum.”); R. Maganlal & Co., 942 F.2d at 167 (as plaintiffs choice of forum is enti-. tied to deference, forum non conveniens dismissal is only permissible where the relevant considerations “tilt[] strongly in favor of trial in the foreign forum”); cf. Bell v. Hood, 327 U.S. 678, 681, 66 S.Ct. 773, 90 L.Ed. 939 (1946) (plaintiff is “master” of his or her own lawsuit). While any plaintiffs selection of a forum is entitled to deference, that deference increases as the plaintiffs ties to the forum increase. See, e.g., Murray v. British Broad. Corp., 81 F.3d 287, 290 (2d Cir.1996) (<HOLDING>); see also Piper, 454 U.S. at 255 n. 23, 102 <question> What is the significance of a plaintiff's choice of forum in a legal case? <issues> The significance of a plaintiff's choice of forum <rules> Presumption in favor of plaintiff's choice of forum <analysis> The deference given to a plaintiff's choice of forum increases as the plaintiff's ties to the forum increase. <answer> In a legal case, the plaintiff's choice of forum holds great significance. There is a strong presumption in favor of the plaintiff's choice of forum, which is entitled to deference. This means that the court generally respects and upholds the plaintiff's decision on where to bring the lawsuit. However, the level of deference given to the plaintiff's choice of forum increases as the plaintiff's connections or ties to the chosen forum increase. This means that if the plaintiff has strong ties to the chosen forum, such as residence or business operations, the court will be more inclined to maintain the case in that forum. Ultimately, the choice of forum has an impact on the convenience and fairness of the trial process. <end>

Accordingly, summary judgment will be allowed for Count VII because it fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted. 3. Strict Liability. Defendants have moved for summary judgment on Count II of plaintiffs Amended Complaint, which seeks to hold defendants strictly liable for the settlement of plaintiffs buildings. Defendants contend that Massachusetts law does not allow strict liability for subsidence of buildings from the pumping of subsurface water. Rather, negligence must be shown to recover. See Gamer v. Milton, 346 Mass. 617, 620-21, 195 N.E.2d 65 (1964) (<HOLDING>). In response, plaintiff points to the <question> Can defendants be held strictly liable for the settlement of plaintiff's buildings? <issues> Whether defendants can be held strictly liable for the settlement of plaintiff's buildings <rules> According to Massachusetts law, strict liability does not apply to subsidence of buildings from the pumping of subsurface water. Negligence must be shown to recover. <analysis> Defendants have moved for summary judgment on Count II of plaintiff's Amended Complaint, arguing that strict liability does not apply. They cite the case of Gamer v. Milton, where it was held that negligence must be shown to recover for subsidence of buildings from the pumping of subsurface water. In response, plaintiff points to other cases that might support their argument. <answer> No, defendants cannot be held strictly liable for the settlement of plaintiff's buildings. Massachusetts law does not allow strict liability for subsidence of buildings from the pumping of subsurface water. Instead, negligence must be shown to recover, as established in the case of Gamer v. Milton. Although the plaintiff may argue otherwise, defendants are likely to succeed in their motion for summary judgment on this count. <end>

<context> and holding that purchase qualified for sale-for-resale exemption). We find 7-Eleven’s analogy to these cases to be apt. The sale-for-resale statute simply requires that the service to which the transfer of tangible personal property is integral be a taxable service— not that it actually be taxed in the particular instance in question. See Tex. Tax Code Ann. § 151.006(a)(3). While it may be true that 7-Eleven will avoid paying sales tax on some of the software that it purchased for transfer to its stores, this is the result mandated by the plain language of the tax code exemption. The courts have long refused to enforce strained readings of tax-exemption statutes for the purpose of preventing lost revenue to the State. See, e.g., Schlusselberg v. Calvert, 443 S.W.2d 695, 697 (Tex.1969) (<HOLDING>). We likewise decline to do so here. The result of 7-Eleven avoiding sales tax on some of the software it purchased for transfer to its stores is mandated by the plain language of the tax code exemption. <answer> No, the sale-for-resale statute does not require that the service be taxed in the particular instance in question. It only requires that the service to which the transfer of tangible personal property is integral be a taxable service. The result of 7-Eleven avoiding sales tax on some of the software it purchased for transfer to its stores is mandated by the plain language of the tax code exemption. <end>

The case Sussman v. U.S. Marshals Serv. (494 F.3d 1106, 1115) also supports this exemption. Rooted in Williamson, the law is well-established that evidence of permissive use defeats the establishment of a prescriptive easement because use that is permissive cannot also be adverse or under a claim of right. See Paine, 400 S.C. at 586, 735 S.E.2d at 538 (quoting Williamson and recognizing that a claimant’s permissive use of landowner’s property cannot begin to ripen into a prescriptive easement until the claimant makes a distinct and positive assertion of right hostile to the landowner); Horry Cnty. v. Laychur, 315 S.C. 364, 434 S.E.2d 259 (1993) (<HOLDING>); Williamson, 107 S.C. at 401, 93 S.E. at 16 <question> What is the impact of permissive use on the establishment of a prescriptive easement? <issues> The impact of permissive use on the establishment of a prescriptive easement <rules> Evidence of permissive use defeats the establishment of a prescriptive easement <analysis> Permissive use is when permission is granted by the landowner and there is no adverse use or use under a claim of right. The law, as established in Williamson, states that use that is permissive cannot also be adverse or under a claim of right. In order for a prescriptive easement to be established, the claimant must make a distinct and positive assertion of right hostile to the landowner's property. <answer> Permissive use has a negative impact on the establishment of a prescriptive easement. When permission is granted by the landowner, there is no adverse use or use under a claim of right. Evidence of permissive use defeats the establishment of a prescriptive easement. In order for a prescriptive easement to be established, the claimant must make a distinct and positive assertion of right hostile to the landowner's property, as recognized in the case of Williamson. Therefore, permissive use prevents the development of a prescriptive easement. <end>

R. 408 (emphasis supplied). Because the State successfully proved the relevancy, probative value, and lack of unfair prejudice of the $5000-showing that the $5000 was evidence of charged conduct in 1994-95-there was no abuse of discretion in admitting the evidence. However, to preclude argument on the matter, the better course would have been to amend the dates on the charging information. See, e.g., Brown v. State, 728 N.E.2d 876, 880 (Ind.2000) (<HOLDING>). Howard attempts to analogize his case to <question> What specific aspects or matters are being debated or questioned? <issues> The issue being debated or questioned is the admissibility of the evidence showing narcotics odor on the bills found twenty-four days after the year 1995 had concluded as evidence of a conspiracy to obtain and deliver cocaine that had taken place during 1995. <rules> The relevant legal rule in question is Evid. R. 408, which deals with the admissibility of evidence of compromises, such as settlement negotiations between parties. The rule specifies that evidence of compromises shall not be admissible to prove liability or invalidity of the claim or its amount. However, the rule provides an exception that such evidence may be admissible for other purposes, such as proving bias, prejudice, or to negate a contention of undue delay. Weatherly complains only of the lack of an objection as to expertise and reliability, however. The State established the expertise of the officer to express the opinion and a sufficient basis for this opinion. See Hernandez v. State, 53 S.W.3d 742, 751 (Tex.App.-Houston [1st Dist.] 2001, pet. ref'd) (stating that experience may provide a sufficient basis for an expert’s testimony); Hardin v. State, 20 S.W.3d 84, 92 (Tex.App.-Texarkana 2000, pet. ref'd) (<HOLDING>). The evidence indicated appellant’s actions <question> Why was the officer's testimony considered an inadmissible expert opinion? <issues> Admissibility of the officer's testimony as an expert opinion <rules> Requirement of expertise and reliability for expert opinion testimony <analysis> The officer's testimony was considered inadmissible because it was deemed unreliable and the officer lacked expertise <answer> The officer's testimony was considered an inadmissible expert opinion because it was found to be unreliable and the officer lacked the necessary expertise. In order for opinion testimony to be admissible, it must meet the requirements of expertise and reliability. However, even if the testimony did not require expertise, an objection was necessary to preserve any error by the trial court in allowing the opinion to be expressed by the officer. In this case, Weatherly complained only about the lack of objection regarding the officer's expertise and reliability. The State, on the other hand, established the expertise of the officer to express the opinion and provided a sufficient basis for this opinion. The case law cited, Hernandez v. State and Hardin v. State, both support the notion that experience may provide a sufficient basis for an expert's testimony. Therefore, the officer's testimony was considered inadmissible due to its unreliability and lack of expertise. <end>

He is absolutely immune from liability for damages if he was gathering evidence to present to the trier of fact. See Ybarra, 723 F.2d at 679. Bogan and Ingram would be protected only by qualified immunity, however, if they were conducting an investigation to determine whether probable cause existed to arrest Broam and Manning. Coe, 728 F.2d 97, 103 (2d Cir.1984) (determining that, “when a prosecutor engages in or authorizes and directs illegal wiretaps” and “the wiretapping is ... investigative in nature,” the prosecutors are only “entitled to qualified, rather than absolute, immunity”); Jacobson v. Rose, 592 F.2d 515, 524 (9th Cir.1978) (<HOLDING>); Guerro v. Mulhearn, 498 F.2d 1249, 1255-56 <question> What is the difference between absolute immunity and qualified immunity in the context of gathering evidence and conducting investigations? <issues> Difference between absolute immunity and qualified immunity in gathering evidence and conducting investigations <rules> In the context of gathering evidence to present to the trier of fact, individuals are absolutely immune from liability for damages. However, in the context of conducting an investigation to determine probable cause for arrest, individuals are protected only by qualified immunity. <analysis> The key difference lies in the purpose and nature of the conduct. Gathering evidence to present to the trier of fact is considered a core function, and individuals enjoy absolute immunity from liability for damages. This means that they cannot be held personally liable for any potential harm caused during the gathering of evidence. On the other hand, when conducting an investigation to determine probable cause for arrest, individuals are protected by qualified immunity. This means that they can be held liable for damages if their conduct was found to be unreasonable or in violation of clearly established laws or constitutional rights. <answer> Absolute immunity applies when individuals are gathering evidence to present to the trier of fact. They are protected from any liability for damages, regardless of the potential harm caused. On the other hand, qualified immunity applies when individuals are conducting investigations to determine probable cause for arrest. Under qualified immunity, individuals can be held liable for damages if their conduct is found to be unreasonable or in violation of established laws or constitutional rights. <end>

<context> No. 15 at 6.) The Court agrees. The United States is a sovereign nation, and as such, it may not be sued absent consent. See Lehman v. Nakshian, 453 U.S. 156, 160, 101 S.Ct. 2698, 69 L.Ed.2d 548 (1981); Gilbert v. DaGrossa, 756 F.2d 1455, 1458 (9th Cir.1985.) If the United States has not consented to the suit, subject matter jurisdiction is lacking and the complaint must be dismissed. Fed.R.Civ.P. 12(h)(3); United States v. Mitchell, 463 U.S. 206, 212, 103 S.Ct. 2961, 77 L.Ed.2d 580 (1983); Gilbert, 756 F.2d at 1458. Administrative prerequisites aimed at agency resolution of a claim prior to suit generally are jurisdictional, as the Government’s consent to be sued is premised upon adherence to the prerequisites. See, e.g., Sommatino v. United States, 255 F.3d 704, 708 (9th Cir.2001) (<HOLDING>); Jerves v. United States, 966 F.2d 517, 519 <question> What is the importance of consent in relation to suing the United States? <issues> The importance of consent in relation to suing the United States <rules> Lehman v. Nakshian, 453 U.S. 156, 160, 101 S.Ct. 2698, 69 L.Ed.2d 548 (1981); Gilbert v. DaGrossa, 756 F.2d 1455, 1458 (9th Cir.1985); Fed.R.Civ.P. 12(h)(3); United States v. Mitchell, 463 U.S. 206, 212, 103 S.Ct. 2961, 77 L.Ed.2d 580 (1983) <analysis> The United States is a sovereign nation and cannot be sued without its consent. If the United States has not consented to the suit, subject matter jurisdiction is lacking and the complaint must be dismissed. Administrative prerequisites aimed at agency resolution of a claim prior to suit generally are jurisdictional, as the Government’s consent to be sued is premised upon adherence to the prerequisites. <answer> Consent is of utmost importance when it comes to suing the United States. As a sovereign nation, the United States cannot be sued without its consent. This principle is supported by legal cases such as Lehman v. Nakshian and Gilbert v. DaGrossa. If the United States has not given its consent to the suit, subject matter jurisdiction is lacking, and the complaint must be dismissed. Additionally, administrative prerequisites aimed at resolving a claim with the relevant agency before filing a lawsuit are generally considered jurisdictional, as the Government's consent to be sued is dependent on adhering to these prerequisites. Therefore, it is essential to obtain the United States' consent before initiating any legal action against it. <end>

<context> will not state a cause of action for retaliatory discharge.” Turner, 233 Ill. 2d at 502-03. The Complaint here fails to state a cause of action. Although attorney honesty and fidelity are vital to the legal system and a matter in the public interest, we do not believe that a former law firm employee can be immune from the general rule of at-will employment merely by complaining to the Firm and its attorneys prior to being fired about deceitful but seemingly legal billing practices he no longer wishes to participate in. While we do not condone the Firm’s alleged misconduct here, we are not persuaded that plaintiffs allegation of “honesty and fidelity” in the legal system satisfies the supreme court’s “narrow definition of public policy” in retaliatory discharge cases. Id. at 507-08 (<HOLDING>). We affirm the dismissal of the Complaint. <question> Can a former law firm employee be immune from the general rule of at-will employment by complaining about deceitful billing practices? <issues> Whether a former law firm employee can be immune from at-will employment <rules> The general rule of at-will employment <analysis> The former law firm employee's complaint about deceitful billing practices and its impact on at-will employment <answer> No, a former law firm employee cannot be immune from the general rule of at-will employment merely by complaining about deceitful billing practices. While attorney honesty and fidelity are important, the court does not consider complaining about deceitful billing practices as satisfying the narrow definition of public policy in retaliatory discharge cases. <end>

Angelone, 321 F.3d 442, 464 (4th Cir.2003) (“Walton had no constitutional right to insist on the appointment of any particular expert.”); Wilson v. Greene, 155 F.3d 396, 401-02 (4th Cir.1998) (<HOLDING>). The defendant does not contend otherwise. <question> Can the defendant choose their own expert witness in a federal capital trial? <issues> Whether the defendant is entitled to choose their own expert witness in a federal capital trial. <rules> The government contends that the defendant is not entitled to choose their own expert witness. <analysis> The government's argument is supported by legal precedent. In Ake v. Oklahoma, the Supreme Court held that an indigent defendant does not have a constitutional right to choose a psychiatrist of their personal liking. The court's concern is that the defendant has access to a competent psychiatrist. Similarly, in Walton v. Angelone, the Fourth Circuit stated that a defendant has no constitutional right to insist on the appointment of any particular expert. Thus, based on these precedents, it can be concluded that the defendant is not entitled to choose their own expert witness in a federal capital trial. <answer> No, the defendant is not entitled to choose their own expert witness in a federal capital trial. The government's argument is supported by legal precedent, including the Supreme Court case Ake v. Oklahoma and the Fourth Circuit case Walton v. Angelone. <end>

<context> process to convict a defendant when he is legally incompetent. United States v. Mason, 52 F.3d 1286, 1289 (4th Cir.1995). “Congress has safeguarded this [due process] right by providing that trial courts conduct competency hearings” under specified circumstances. Id. (citing 18 U.S.C. § 4241(a)). Of relevance here, when neither party to a criminal trial moves for a competency hearing, the district court shall order such a hearing on its own motion[ ] if there is reasonable cause to believe that the defendant may presently be suffering from a mental disease or defect rendering him mentally incompetent to the extent that he is unable to understand the nature and consequences of the proceedings against him or to assist properly in his defense. § 4241(a); see also Mason, 52 F.3d at 1289 (<HOLDING>). Whether such reasonable cause exists, <question> Under what circumstances should a district court order a competency hearing for a defendant? <issues> Determining when a district court should order a competency hearing for a defendant. <rules> If there is reasonable cause to believe that the defendant may presently be suffering from a mental disease or defect rendering him mentally incompetent to the extent that he is unable to understand the nature and consequences of the proceedings against him or to assist properly in his defense. <analysis> According to 18 U.S.C. § 4241(a), when neither party to a criminal trial moves for a competency hearing, the district court shall order such a hearing on its own motion if there is reasonable cause to believe that the defendant may presently be suffering from a mental disease or defect rendering him mentally incompetent, making him unable to understand the nature and consequences of the proceedings against him or to assist properly in his defense. <answer> A district court should order a competency hearing for a defendant if there is reasonable cause to believe that the defendant may presently be suffering from a mental disease or defect rendering him mentally incompetent to the extent that he is unable to understand the nature and consequences of the proceedings against him or to assist properly in his defense. This requirement is outlined in 18 U.S.C. § 4241(a), and it applies when neither party to a criminal trial moves for a competency hearing. <end>

<context> 545 (1958). The “tied” product is typically from a different but interdependent market (i.e. printer and printer cartridges). Such tying agreements can constitute an injury to competition when “the seller has market power over the tying product,” and the seller “can leverage this market power through tying arrangements to exclude other sellers of the tied product.” Cascade Health Solutions v. PeaceHealth, 515 F.3d 883, 912 (9th Cir.2008). “Bundling” is defined as “the practice of offering, for a single price, two or more goods or services that could be sold separately.” Id. at 884. Bundling can constitute an injury to competition when a bundler is able to use discounting, for example, to “exclude rivals who do not sell as great a number of product lines.” Id. at 897; see id. at 910(<HOLDING>). III We consider plaintiffs’ complaint in <question> What is the definition of 'bundling' in the context of tying agreements? <issues> Definition of 'bundling' in tying agreements <rules> The definition of 'bundling' is the practice of offering, for a single price, two or more goods or services that could be sold separately. <analysis> In the context of tying agreements, 'bundling' refers to the practice of offering multiple goods or services together at a single price, even though they could be sold separately. This allows the seller to leverage their market power over the tying product and exclude other sellers of the tied product. By offering a bundle, the seller can attract customers with the convenience and cost-saving benefits of purchasing multiple products together, and potentially exclude rivals who do not sell as many product lines. <answer> In the context of tying agreements, 'bundling' refers to the practice of offering, for a single price, two or more goods or services that could be sold separately. It allows the seller to leverage their market power over the tying product and exclude other sellers of the tied product. By offering a bundle, the seller can attract customers with the convenience and cost-saving benefits of purchasing multiple products together, and potentially exclude rivals who do not sell as many product lines. <end>

<context> F.2d 65, 67 (9th Cir. 1971). Trial courts must generally exercise their discretion in favor of awarding prejudgment interest in admiralty tort claims. Self v. Great Lakes Dredge & Dock Co., 832 F.2d 1540, 1550-51 (11th Cir. 1987). Accordingly, because DEA chemist’s reports are created expressly for use in criminal prosecutions as a substitute for live testimony against the accused, such reports are testimonial, whether or not they happen to meet this jurisdiction’s definition of a business record. Freeman, 2002 WL 539061, at *1 n. <question> What is the effect of a technical defect in the service of process on the validity of the service? <issues> The specific aspect being debated is the effect of a technical defect in the service of process on its validity. <rules> The relevant rule is that technical defects in the form of the summons and the complaint do not invalidate an otherwise proper and successful delivery of process under Fed. R.Civ.P. 4. <analysis> According to Mut. Fire Ins. Co., technical defects in the form of the summons and the complaint do not render the service of process legally defective. Harris states that technical defects in the service of process do not invalidate it. As long as the delivery of process is otherwise proper and successful, under Fed. R.Civ.P. 4, the service remains valid. Similarly, courts have held that technical defects in the service of process do not invalidate it if the plaintiff has substantially complied with the applicable state-law rule. <end>

District of Columbia case, injunctive relief was not granted based on assertions about lost opportunities and market share. <end>

We therefore affirm the trial court’s order dismissing the appellees’ complaint as moot. As to the attorney’s fees and costs awarded to the appellees as the prevailing parties, we also affirm. Section 709.08(11), Florida Statutes (2007), provides that the prevailing party in power of attorney litigation is entitled to attorney’s fees and costs. The determination of the prevailing party for the purpose of awarding attorney’s fees and costs is based on whether the party seeking fees succeeded on any significant issue(s) in the litigation. Constructive Discharge A constructive discharge occurs when' an employer makes an employee’s working conditions so intolerable and unbearable because of his or her protected status that á reasonable person in that employee’s position would have felt compelled to resign. <context> Chief Judge. Arnold Ellis, the appellant, is serving a 12-year prison term as a result of his 1983 conviction for drug offenses. <context> under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (“ADEA”), 29 U.S.C. § 621, the ADEA incorporates enforcement provisions of the FLSA, including the collective action provisions of 29 U.S.C. § 216(b). 9 . Some courts refer to the process of opting in to a collective action as "joinder.” See Grayson v. K Mart Corp., 79 F.3d 1086, 1096 (11th Cir. 1996) (Garth, J.) (referring to a certification of an ADEA collective action as "permitting opt-in joinder of ‘similarly situated’ plaintiffs”). But opt-in plaintiffs are held to a lesser standard than FLSA named plaintiffs or other plaintiffs who jo.in in .civil actions. For instance, ADEA opt-in plaintiffs do not need to exhaust administrative remedies, while ADEA named plaintiffs do. See Lusardi v. Lechner, 855 F.2d 1062, 1078 (3d Cir. 1988) (<HOLDING>). Moreover, opt-in plaintiffs are held to a <question> What is the difference between ADEA opt-in plaintiffs and ADEA named plaintiffs in terms of exhausting administrative remedies? <issues> Difference in exhausting administrative remedies for ADEA opt-in plaintiffs and ADEA named plaintiffs <rules> ADEA incorporates enforcement provisions of the FLSA, including the collective action provisions of 29 U.S.C. § 216(b). ADEA opt-in plaintiffs do not need to exhaust administrative remedies, while ADEA named plaintiffs do. <analysis> Under the ADEA, opt-in plaintiffs who join a collective action are not required to exhaust administrative remedies, unlike named plaintiffs who file individual civil actions under the ADEA. This means that opt-in plaintiffs can participate in a collective action without going through the administrative process, while named plaintiffs must first exhaust their administrative remedies before filing a civil action. <answer> In the context of the ADEA, there is a difference in the requirement to exhaust administrative remedies between opt-in plaintiffs and named plaintiffs. Opt-in plaintiffs who join a collective action are not required to exhaust administrative remedies, while named plaintiffs who file individual civil actions under the ADEA must first exhaust their administrative remedies before proceeding with the lawsuit. <end>

<context> In support of his argument, Mattingly relies solely upon a statement in Johnson that, generally, a taking involves "an actual interference with, or disturbance of property rights, which are not merely consequential, or incidental injuries to property or property rights...." Id. at 804 (quoting School Town of Andrews v. Heiney, 178 Ind. 1, 7, 98 N.E. 628, 630 (1912)). Johnson does not stand for the proposition that a taking occurs each time a party asserts its property rights. Johnson dealt with the creation of a regulated drain, and we held that the establishment of such worked no additional taking of property "save that incidentally required by the county to enter upon the land to repair and maintain the drain." Id.; see Bemis v. Guirl Drainage Co., 182 Ind. 36, 105 N.E. 496 (1914) (<HOLDING>). No unconstitutional taking occurred when the <question> Based on the passage, what specific legal issue is being debated or questioned? <issues> Whether the statement in Johnson regarding 'an actual interference with, or disturbance of property rights' is the sole requirement for a taking to occur. <rules> The statement in Johnson that a taking involves 'an actual interference with, or disturbance of property rights, which are not merely consequential, or incidental injuries to property or property rights' <analysis> Mattingly relies solely upon the statement in Johnson as support for his argument, suggesting that the requirement of 'an actual interference with, or disturbance of property rights' is the sole criteria for a taking to occur. <answer> The specific legal issue being debated or questioned is whether the statement in Johnson, which defines a taking as 'an actual interference with, or disturbance of property rights,' is the sole requirement for a taking to occur. Mattingly relies solely upon this statement as support for his argument, suggesting that any interference or disturbance of property rights, which are not merely consequential or incidental injuries, would constitute a taking. However, it is important to note that Johnson does not stand for the proposition that a taking occurs each time a party asserts its property rights. <end>

<context> of law or unwarranted inferences cast in the form of factual allegations. See Gregory v. Shelby County, 220 F.3d 433, 446 (6th Cir.2000). In order to survive a motion to dismiss, a complaint must provide the grounds of the entitlement to relief, which requires more than labels and conclusions, and a formulaic recitation of the elements of a cause of action. See Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, — U.S. —, —, 127 S.Ct. 1955, 1964-65, 167 L.Ed.2d 929 (2007). That is,“[f]actual allegations must be enough to raise a right to relief above the speculative level, on the assumption that all the allegations in the complaint are true (even if doubtful in fact).” Id. (internal citation omitted); see also Association of Cleveland Fire Fighters v. City of Cleveland, 502 F.3d 545, 548 (6th Cir.2007) (<HOLDING>). Accordingly, the claims set forth in a <question> What is required for a complaint to survive a motion to dismiss? <issues> Requirements for a complaint to survive a motion to dismiss <rules> Grounds of the entitlement to relief, more than labels and conclusions, and a formulaic recitation of the elements of a cause of action <analysis> The factual allegations must raise a right to relief above the speculative level, assuming all allegations in the complaint are true <answer> In order for a complaint to survive a motion to dismiss, it must provide the grounds of the entitlement to relief, which goes beyond labels and conclusions, and a formulaic recitation of the elements of a cause of action. The factual allegations must be sufficient to raise a right to relief above the speculative level, even if there are doubts about their truth. This requirement was established in the case of Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, where the Court emphasized that factual allegations should be more than speculation. Therefore, a complaint must contain enough factual allegations to satisfy these criteria in order to withstand a motion to dismiss. <end>

Such agreements are contractual in nature and become binding upon the parties onee the trial court merges and incorporates such into the divorcee decree. In re Marriage of Loeb, 614 N.E.2d 954, 957 (Ind.Ct.App.19983). This court will enforce an agreement concerning the custody and support of children even though the divorcee court would otherwise not have the authority to do as the parties agreed. The court will enforce an agreement concerning the custody and support of children even though the court would otherwise not have the authority to do as the parties agreed. <analysis> In this situation, it would depend on the specific terms of the settlement agreement between Stephanie's parents. The Tenth Circuit has also addressed the authority of the states to execute search warrants and to arrest individuals on reservations. In United States v. Baker, 894 F.2d 1144 (10th Cir.1990), state authorities executed a search warrant on a tribal reservation. The Tenth Circuit concluded that the search warrant was invalid, and therefore the evidence should have been suppressed, because the state had no jurisdiction over the reservation to enforce its laws — including the execution of a search warrant — unless Congress consented to the state's jurisdiction. Id. at 1147. See also Ross v. Neff, 905 F.2d 1349, 1354-55 (10th Cir.1990) (<HOLDING>). 6 . Baker is that the search warrant executed by state authorities on a tribal reservation was invalid. The Tenth Circuit determined that the state had no jurisdiction over the reservation to enforce its laws, including the execution of a search warrant, unless Congress consented to the state's jurisdiction. Therefore, the evidence obtained through the search warrant should have been suppressed. <end>

Even if the jury had found entrapment on the first count, it would not preclude a rejection of that defense for the second count. This means that the defendant can still be prosecuted for the second count even if the jury was unable to reach a verdict on the entrapment defense for the first count. <end>

The presumed prejudice exception to Strickland has been found to apply where there was an actual or constructive denial of counsel, the state interfered with counsel’s assistance, or counsel had an actual conflict of interest. The passage also mentions that the presumed prejudice exception to Strickland can apply in cases of actual or constructive denial of counsel, interference by the state with counsel's assistance, or when counsel has an actual conflict of interest. The presumed prejudice exception to Strickland can also apply in cases of actual or constructive denial of counsel, interference by the state with counsel's assistance, or when counsel has an actual conflict of interest. However, it is important to keep in mind that such instances are rare according to the U.S. Supreme Court. <end>

<context> When a complaint seeking review of governmental action is combined with one or more counts alleging causes of action that are independent of the court’s review of the governmental action, the court will be called upon to act in two distinct capacities — as an appellate court and as a trial court. <context> of a fire occurring” was “insufficient” for defendants to claim immunity. Geiger at 494. Similarly, N.C. Gen. Stat. § 58-82-5 requires that the alleged negligent act occur “at the scene” of a reported fire before a rural volunteer fire department can assert immunity. The fact that plaintiff’s wreck occurred where defendants had filled their fire trucks with water from a fire hydrant, one-half mile away from the reported fire, is insufficient for defendants to claim immunity. The words “at the scene” provide immunity for defendants for acts and omissions only in a specific place. A broader reading of the statute would be inconsistent with the plain meaning of the words. See State ex rel. McDonald v. Whatcom Cty. Etc., 575 P.2d 1094 (Wash. Ct. App. 1978) aff’d, 593 P.2d 546 (Wash. 1979) (<HOLDING>). II. <context> review. (d) Martin argues that the prosecutor’s closing argument repeatedly misled the jury regarding the effect of a sentence of guilty but mentally ill. While it was not improper for the prosecutor to state that it would not be justice for the jury to impose a sentence of guilty but mentally ill if it was not supported by the evidence, we agree that it was improper to refer to such a verdict using the phrases, “a break” and “a pass,” and by making similar arguments. We note, however, that such language would have been permissible in the sentencing phase where, regardless of whether the jury had found Martin guilty or guilty but mentally ill, the jury would be choosing between imposing a death sentence or granting mercy. See Lewis v. State, 279 Ga. 756, 764 (12) (620 SE2d 778) (2005) (<HOLDING>). Because Martin did not object to this line of <question> Why was it considered improper for the prosecutor to refer to a guilty but mentally ill verdict as 'a break' or 'a pass'? <issues> Improper language used by the prosecutor <rules> Professional conduct <analysis> The prosecutor's use of phrases like 'a break' and 'a pass' to describe a guilty but mentally ill verdict could potentially bias the jury and influence their decision. Such language implies leniency or a lighter sentence, which may be misleading to the jury. The purpose of the prosecutor's closing argument should be to present the facts and evidence impartially, without using language that could unduly sway the jury's perception of the guilty but mentally ill verdict. <answer> It was considered improper for the prosecutor to refer to a guilty but mentally ill verdict as 'a break' or 'a pass' because it could potentially bias the jury and influence their decision. Such language implies leniency or a lighter sentence, which may be misleading to the jury. The purpose of the prosecutor's closing argument should be to present the facts and evidence impartially, without using language that could unduly sway the jury's perception of the guilty but mentally ill verdict. Professional conduct requires prosecutors to refrain from using language that may unfairly affect the jury's decision-making process. <end>

<context> has the burden to show why the defendant’s voluntary absence at the trial after receiving actual notice of the trial date, time, and place, does not constitute a knowing and voluntary waiver of the right to be present. The State does not have the burden of proving that a defendant’s absence is unjustified. To the contrary, a defendant has the burden of proving the absence was justified. Where, as here, the record reflects that a defendant was informed in court of the time and place of trial, and he or she fails to appear and also fails to file the appropriate motion challenging the waiver, the failure to make the appropriate motion before the trial court constitutes a second waiver pursuant to Rule 3:16(b). See State v. Butler, 278 N.J.Super. 93, 101, 650 A.2d 397 (App.Div.1994) (<HOLDING>). We also reject as impractical, the Appellate <question> What is the burden of proof regarding a defendant's voluntary absence at trial? <issues> The burden of proof regarding a defendant's voluntary absence at trial <rules> The burden is on the defendant to show why their voluntary absence does not constitute a knowing and voluntary waiver of the right to be present <analysis> The defendant has the burden of proving that their absence was justified <answer> The burden of proof regarding a defendant's voluntary absence at trial lies with the defendant. They must show why their voluntary absence, despite receiving notice of the trial date, time, and place, does not constitute a knowing and voluntary waiver of the right to be present. The state is not required to prove that the defendant's absence is unjustified. Instead, the defendant has the burden of proving that their absence was justified. If the defendant fails to appear in court and also fails to file the appropriate motion challenging the waiver, the failure to make the appropriate motion before the trial court constitutes a second waiver. This means that the defendant is considered to have waived their right to be present at the trial. The burden is on the defendant to provide evidence and arguments to support their claim of justification. <end>

Keane, 239 F.3d 191, 202 (2d Cir.2001) (granting writ of habeas corpus because counsel’s cumulative errors — including failure to effectively challenge only evidence of physical sexual abuse and expert testimony based on unnamed available studies — amounted to constitutional ineffectiveness and prejudiced petitioner).
