In other words, the court examines the overall impact of the errors committed by the counsel to determine whether the petitioner has been prejudiced to an extent that violates their constitutional rights. <end>

<context> expect criminal defense lawyers to be seers, but we must demand that they at least apprise themselves of the applicable law and provide their clients with a reasonably accurate description of it. Id. at 355. This element of gross misinformation was also present in Strader v. Garrison, 611 F.2d 61 (4th Cir.1979), where defense counsel provided, prior to his client’s guilty plea, notably inaccurate information regarding a parole eligibility date and, as was the case later in Ostrander, the defendant relied upon the advice in deciding to plead guilty. Consequently, the Court said, “When the erroneous advice induces the plea, permitting him to start over again is the imperative remedy for the constitutional deprivation.” 611 F.2d at 65. See also Richardson, 397 U.S. at 772, 90 S.Ct. 1441 (<HOLDING>); United States v. Fisher, 711 F.3d 460, 465-66 <question> What is the significance of the case Strader v. Garrison in relation to the provision of inaccurate information by defense counsel? <issues> The significance of the case Strader v. Garrison in relation to the provision of inaccurate information by defense counsel. <rules> The rule established in Strader v. Garrison is that when defense counsel provides notably inaccurate information prior to a guilty plea, and the defendant relies upon that advice in making the decision to plead guilty, it constitutes a constitutional deprivation. <analysis> In the case of Strader v. Garrison, the defense counsel provided grossly inaccurate information regarding the parole eligibility date to the defendant prior to their guilty plea. This inaccurate advice influenced the defendant's decision to plead guilty. The court held that when erroneous advice by defense counsel induces a plea, the imperative remedy for the constitutional deprivation is to allow the defendant to start over again. <answer> The case of Strader v. Garrison is significant in highlighting the consequences of defense counsel providing notably inaccurate information to a defendant prior to a guilty plea. In this case, defense counsel inaccurately advised the defendant regarding the parole eligibility date, leading the defendant to plead guilty based on this misleading advice. The court held that such erroneous advice is a constitutional deprivation and concluded that the appropriate remedy in such cases is to allow the defendant to start over again. This underscores the importance of defense counsel being well-informed about the applicable law and providing their clients with accurate information. <end>

Zamora points to: (1) comments al legedly made by Superintendent Rounds that New Mexico’s Governor (an Hispanic woman) is inept; (2) Rounds’ hiring a man who had authorized a social experiment at a New Mexico high school that gave the appearance of race discrimination; (3) the reassignment of Zamora’s duties in 2007 and 2008 to Caucasians; and (4) comments made by two co-workers in conversations surreptitiously recorded by Zamora following his termination in which they opined that Superintendent Rounds had engaged in racially discriminatory practices. To establish pretext from such comments or actions, Zamora must tie them to his termination, which he has not done. See Johnson v. Weld Cnty., 594 F.3d 1202, 1218 (10th Cir.2010) (<HOLDING>). Ill The judgment of the district court is <question> What must Zamora do to establish pretext from the comments or actions of Superintendent Rounds? <issues> Establishing pretext in relation to comments or actions of Superintendent Rounds <rules> Tying the comments or actions to Zamora's termination <analysis> Based on the information provided, Zamora must establish a clear connection between the comments or actions of Superintendent Rounds (alleged racism) and his own termination. This requires demonstrating how the comments or actions directly led to his termination and that they were not merely incidental or unrelated. <answer> In order to establish pretext from the comments or actions of Superintendent Rounds, Zamora must provide evidence that directly connects these comments or actions to his own termination. This requires demonstrating a clear causal link between the alleged racism of Superintendent Rounds and Zamora's termination, showing that the comments or actions were not incidental or unrelated to the termination decision. Without establishing this connection, it would be difficult for Zamora to successfully argue pretext in relation to the alleged racist behavior of Superintendent Rounds. <end>

Since there is no federal common law of contracts, the relevant legal rules would be the state substantive law. <analysis> Based on the Supreme Court case of Erie R. Co. v. Tompkins, 304 U.S. 64, 78, 58 S.Ct. 817, 82 L.Ed. 1188 (1938), the Court held that there is no federal common law of contracts and state substantive law applies. Therefore, the relevant legal rules in this case would be the contract law principles of the state in which the case is being heard. <answer> The relevant legal rules in this case are the contract law principles of the state in which the case is being heard. General Motors Corp., 19 <question> What authority allows the court to order attorney fees paid by a defendant rather than from the common fund under the common-fund exception to the American Rule? <issues> The authority allowing the court to order attorney fees paid by a defendant rather than from the common fund <rules> The common-fund doctrine <analysis> The court notes that the language relied upon by the plaintiff in Burk for allowing the court to require the defendants to pay the fee award directly rather than have the fees paid from the common fund appears to have been stricken on re-hearing. Plaintiff has not pointed to any other authority allowing the court to order attorney fees paid by a defendant rather than from the common fund under the common-fund exception to the American Rule. Because attorney fees are paid from the common fund under the common-fund doctrine, the court concludes that any attorney fees awarded under the common fund doctrine may not be included in determining the amount in controversy. <answer> The authority allowing the court to order attorney fees paid by a defendant rather than from the common fund under the common-fund exception to the American Rule is the common-fund doctrine. However, the court notes that the language relied upon by the plaintiff in Burk for allowing the court to require the defendants to pay the fee award directly rather than have the fees paid from the common fund appears to have been stricken on re-hearing. Plaintiff has not pointed to any other authority allowing the court to order attorney fees paid by a defendant rather than from the common fund under the common-fund exception to the American Rule. Because attorney fees are paid from the common fund under the common-fund doctrine, the court concludes that any attorney fees awarded under the common fund doctrine may not be included in determining the amount in controversy. <end>

<context> Fed.Reg. 68,722 at 68,724-25 (“Although water quality problems also can occur from agricultural storm water discharges and return flows from irrigated agriculture, this area of concern is statutorily exempted from regulation as a point source under the Clean Water Act.”). Plaintiffs argue unpersuasively that the Clean Water Act’s exemptions for irrigated agriculture are inapplicable to defendant’s operations because defendant’s possible over-application of fruit processing wastewater to its crops is more akin to industrial, non-agricultural activities. The only case to support this position was decided seven years before Congress added the exemption for agricultural runoff to the Clean Water Act. United States v. Oxford Royal Mushroom Products, Inc., 487 F.Supp. 852, 854 (E.D.Pa.1980) (<HOLDING>); see Pub.L. 100-4, Title V, §§ 502(a), 503 <question> Is defendant's possible over-application of fruit processing wastewater considered an exempt agricultural activity under the Clean Water Act? <issues> Whether defendant's possible over-application of fruit processing wastewater qualifies for the exemption for irrigated agriculture under the Clean Water Act. <rules> The Clean Water Act statutorily exempts agricultural activities from regulation as a point source. <analysis> Plaintiffs argue that defendant's possible over-application of fruit processing wastewater should not be considered an exempt agricultural activity because it is more akin to industrial, non-agricultural activities. They rely on a case decided before the exemption for agricultural runoff was added to the Clean Water Act. <answer> Defendant's possible over-application of fruit processing wastewater may still be considered an exempt agricultural activity under the Clean Water Act. Although plaintiffs argue that it resembles industrial, non-agricultural activities, the Clean Water Act specifically exempts agricultural activities from regulation as a point source. The fact that a previous case, United States v. Oxford Royal Mushroom Products, Inc., supported plaintiffs' position does not undermine the current exemption for agricultural runoff added by Congress. Therefore, defendant's operations may still be exempt from regulation under the Clean Water Act. <end>

The Court found this “surcharge” to be improper, holding that “federal law provides no authority for bankruptcy courts to deny an .exemption on a ground not specified in the Code” and that § 105(a) does not empower bankruptcy courts to surcharge a debtor’s allowed exemption for payment of administrative expenses, despite the debtor’s fraudulent conduct in claiming the exemption, as doing so contravened § 522. Id, at 1195-96. While the Court’s specific holding was limited to the interpretation of § 522(k), its further comments on the authority of bankruptcy courts to use their § 105 powers to remedy debtor fraud has “affect[ed] a sea-change among lower courts facing this issue.” Mateer v. Ostrander (In re Mateer), 525 B.R. 559, 565 (Bank. D. Mass. 2015) (<HOLDING>). The Supreme Court closely scrutinized § 522 <question> Can bankruptcy courts deny an exemption on grounds not specified in the Code? <issues> The issue is whether bankruptcy courts have the authority to deny an exemption on grounds that are not specified in the Code. <rules> The Court in this case held that federal law does not provide authority for bankruptcy courts to deny an exemption on grounds not specified in the Code. <analysis> Based on the Court's interpretation, bankruptcy courts cannot surcharge a debtor's allowed exemption for payment of administrative expenses, even if the debtor fraudulently claimed the exemption. This is because it would contravene Section 522 of the Code. <answer> No, bankruptcy courts cannot deny an exemption on grounds not specified in the Code. The Court in this case held that federal law does not provide authority for bankruptcy courts to do so. Even if a debtor fraudulently claims an exemption, bankruptcy courts cannot surcharge the exempted amount for payment of administrative expenses, as it would go against Section 522 of the Code. <end>

To this end, the language of the IGRA provides that “Any State ... may enter into a Tribal-State compact governing gaming activities on the Indian lands of the Indian Tribe.” Id. § 2710(d)(3)(B). The only reasonable interpretation of this language is that it authorizes state officials, acting pursuant to their authority held under state law, to enter into gaming compacts on behalf of the state. [¶ 11] The general principle mandating that corporations be recognized as separate, taxable entities from their owners creates some tension with the requirement that income be taxed to the party who earns it. Recognizing that tension, in 1982 the United States Tax Court noted that, in the corporate context, simply identifying who earned the income may be inadequate to allow a determination of how the income should be taxed because corporations can act, and thus earn income, only through their agents. Johnson, 78 T.C. at 890-91; see also Haag v. Comm’r, 88 T.C. 604, 611 (1987); cf. State v. Placzek, 380 A.2d 1010, 1015 (Me.1977) (<HOLDING>). That inadequacy is highlighted when <question> What tension does the requirement that income be taxed to the party who earns it create with the recognition of corporations as separate taxable entities? <issues> The tension between the requirement that income be taxed to the party who earns it and the recognition of corporations as separate taxable entities. <rules> The general principle mandating that corporations be recognized as separate taxable entities from their owners. <analysis> The tension arises because corporations can only act and earn income through their agents, so simply identifying who earned the income may not be enough to determine how the income should be taxed. <answer> The requirement that income be taxed to the party who earns it creates tension with the recognition of corporations as separate taxable entities. This tension arises because corporations can only act and earn income through their agents, so simply identifying who earned the income may not be enough to determine how the income should be taxed. <end>

Zip Feed Mills, Inc., 997 F.2d <question> What does direct evidence refer to in the context of pregnancy discrimination? <issues> Definition of direct evidence in the context of pregnancy discrimination <rules> Direct evidence is evidence that demonstrates a specific link between the alleged discriminatory animus and the challenged employment decision, sufficient to support a finding by a reasonable fact finder that an illegitimate criterion actually motivated the employer's decision to take adverse employment action. <analysis> In the passage, it is mentioned that direct evidence of pregnancy discrimination is evidence that shows a specific link between the alleged discriminatory animus (bias) and the adverse employment decision, specifically related to the plaintiffs' pregnancy. <context> Bankruptcy Procedure 4004. Id. at 456-57, 124 S.Ct. 906. Rule 9006 allows extension of the Rule 4004 time limit only to the extent permitted by Rule 4004. <context> with Turnage that the postconviction court’s formulation of the second Larrison prong was erroneous insofar as it seemed to focus its inquiry on whether there was sufficient evidence to convict Turnage even without Quantez’s testimony. Under the second Larrison prong, the court is to ask whether the petitioner has demonstrated “that without the [recanting witness’s] testimony, the jury might have reached a different conclusion.” Williams, 692 N.W.2d at 896; see also Hooper, 680 N.W.2d at 96 (affirming the postconviction court’s holding that second prong not met because “even without [the recanting witness’s] testimony, the strength of the other evidence presented at trial was such that the jury would not likely have reached a different conclusion”); cf. Opsahl II, 677 N.W.2d at 424 (<HOLDING>). As these cases make clear, the second <question> What is the second Larrison prong and how does it apply to the case of Turnage? <issues> Understanding the second Larrison prong and its application to the case of Turnage. <rules> The second Larrison prong requires the court to determine whether the petitioner has demonstrated that without the testimony of a recanting witness, the jury might have reached a different conclusion. <analysis> In the case of Turnage, the postconviction court incorrectly focused on whether there was sufficient evidence to convict Turnage even without Quantez's testimony. The court should have focused on whether the absence of Quantez's testimony could have led the jury to reach a different conclusion. Other cases, such as Williams and Hooper, provide guidance on how to apply the second Larrison prong. <answer> The second Larrison prong requires the court to consider whether the petitioner has shown that without the testimony of a recanting witness, the jury might have reached a different conclusion. In the case of Turnage, the postconviction court made an error by focusing on the sufficiency of evidence to convict Turnage even without Quantez's testimony. The court should have assessed whether the absence of Quantez's testimony could have influenced the jury's decision. Other cases, such as Williams and Hooper, provide examples of how the second Larrison prong has been applied in similar situations. <end>

The constitutionally secured guarantee of equal protection under the law “ ‘implies that all litigants similarly situated may appeal to courts for both relief and defense under like conditions, with like protection, and without discrimination.’ ” Conley v. This means that the classification must be based on a reasonable purpose or goal that the government seeks to achieve. This means that the classification must have a reasonable connection to a purpose or goal that the government seeks to achieve. If the classification lacks a rational basis or is arbitrary, it would be considered invalid under the equal protection guarantee. <end>

L.R. 7.1(g)(3), no additional briefing is permitted without the permission of the court. Therefore, the district court did not abuse its discretion in striking the Kinsey declaration as untimely. <answer> The reason for striking the Kinsey declaration as untimely was that it was submitted after the deadline for the summary judgment opposition had lapsed, violating D. Or. L.R. 7.1(g)(3) which states that no additional briefing is permitted without the permission of the court. The district court did not abuse its discretion in striking the Kinsey declaration. <end>

The striking feature of a typical no-injury class is that the plaintiffs have either not yet experienced a malfunction because of the alleged defect or have experienced a malfunction but not been harmed by it. Therefore, the plaintiffs in a no-injury products liability case have not suffered any physical harm or out-of-pocket economic loss. Here, the damages sought by the Coghlans are not rooted in the alleged defect of the product as such, but in the fact that they did not receive the benefit of their bargain. Coghlan v. When determining whether a trade dress has secondary meaning, courts consider several factors, including: (1) plaintiffs advertising expenditures; (2) consumer surveys linking the trade dress to a particular source; (3) sales success; -(4) unsolicited media coverage; (5) attempts to plagiarize the trade dress; and (6) the length and exclusivity of the use. <context> L.Ed.2d 471 (1977) (“The bar of the Eleventh Amendment to suit in Federal courts extends to States and state officials in appropriate circumstances ... but does not extend to counties and similar municipal corporations.”). The only Eleventh Amendment question here is whether the Holmes County Court, which is responsible for the policies of its Clerk’s Office and Judge Irving, should be considered an “arm of the state” and thus vested with sovereign immunity. We do not write on a blank slate. Several years ago, we held that an Ohio court of common pleas was an arm of the state for Eleventh Amendment purposes. See Mumford v. Basinski, 105 F.3d 264, 268 (6th Cir.), cert. denied, 522 U.S. 914, 118 S.Ct. 298, 139 L.Ed.2d 229 (1997); see also Foster v. Walsh, 864 F.2d 416, 418 (6th Cir.1988) (<HOLDING>). County of Napa, 217 Cal.App.3d 1551, 266 Cal.Rptr. 682, 687 (Cal.App.1990); Alicia T. v. County of Los Angeles, 222 Cal.App.3d 869, 271 Cal.Rptr. 513, 519-20 (Cal.App.1990) (<HOLDING>). Virginia's felony-murder statute requires a nexus between the felonious act and the resulting death. The nexus requirement is a separate and distinct requirement from the continuing offense concept. <analysis> The passage mentions that the Doane court agreed with the State that there is a continuing offense concept regarding larceny. However, the court refused to extend this concept to satisfy the nexus requirement of Virginia's felony-murder statute. This implies that the continuing offense concept, although recognized in relation to larceny, does not necessarily fulfill the nexus requirement for felony-murder in Virginia. Therefore, it is important to distinguish between the continuing offense concept and the nexus requirement. <answer> The continuing offense concept is a legal fiction of common law that supports venue in the county where stolen property is taken. It is recognized in relation to larceny. However, in the context of Virginia's felony-murder statute, the nexus requirement is a separate and distinct requirement that needs to be satisfied. The passage indicates that although the Doane court acknowledged the continuing offense concept for larceny, it refused to extend this concept to fulfill the nexus requirement for felony-murder in Virginia. Therefore, it is crucial to understand that the continuing offense concept does not automatically satisfy the nexus requirement in Virginia's felony-murder cases. <end>

A party’s subsequent acts will render a case moot if those acts make it impossible for the court to grant “ ‘effectual relief.’ ” Church of Scientology of Cal v. United States, 506 U.S. 9, 12, 113 S.Ct. 447, 121 L.Ed.2d 313 (1992) (quoting Mills v. Green, 159 U.S. 651, 653,16 S.Ct. 132, 40 L.Ed. 293 (1895)). However, because the “[m]ootness of an action relates to the basic dispute between the parties” and “not merely the relief requested,” a case will not be rendered moot by subsequent acts if some of the requested relief remains available. Intrepid v. Pollock, 907 F.2d 1125, 1131 (Fed.Cir.1990); accord Church of Scientology of Cal, 506 U.S. at 12, 113 S.Ct. 447 (<HOLDING>). However, if some of the requested relief remains available, the case will not be rendered moot. <analysis> The significance of subsequent acts in relation to the mootness of a case is that if a party's subsequent acts make it impossible for the court to provide 'effectual relief', the case may be deemed moot. However, if some of the requested relief remains available, the case will not be considered moot. <answer> The significance of subsequent acts in relation to the mootness of a case is that if a party's subsequent acts make it impossible for the court to provide 'effectual relief', the case may be deemed moot. However, if some of the requested relief remains available, the case will not be considered moot. This interpretation is supported by the ruling in Steffel v. Thompson, which states that a party's subsequent acts can render a case moot if they make it impossible for the court to grant 'effectual relief'. It is important to note that the mootness of a case relates to the basic dispute between the parties and not just the relief requested. Therefore, even if some relief remains available, a case can still be considered moot if the basic dispute has been resolved by subsequent acts. <end>

<context> 11, the Eleventh Circuit held in Massengale v. Ray that attorney’s fees cannot be awarded to a pro se attorney litigant. 267 F.3d 1298, 1301-03 (11th Cir.2001). “Because a party proceeding pro se cannot have incurred attorney’s fees as an expense, a district court cannot order a violating party to pay a pro se litigant a reasonable attorney’s fee as part of a sanction.” The court relied, in part, on the fact that “the word ‘attorney’ generally assumes some kind of agency (that is, attorney/client) relationship” and that when a lawyer proceeds pro se, “legal fees are not truly a ‘cost’ of litigation — no independent lawyer has been hired (or must be paid) to pursue the ... complaint.” Id. at 1301 (quoting Ray v. United States Dep’t of Justice, 87 F.3d 1250, 1251 n. 2 (11th Cir.1996) (<HOLDING>)). The court relied on the fact that the word 'attorney' generally assumes an attorney-client relationship, which does not exist when a lawyer proceeds pro se. Therefore, legal fees are not considered a 'cost' of litigation in the case of a pro se litigant. <answer> No, attorney's fees cannot be awarded to a pro se attorney litigant. The Eleventh Circuit held in Massengale v. Ray that attorney's fees cannot be awarded to a pro se attorney litigant because a pro se litigant cannot have incurred attorney's fees as an expense. This is because the word 'attorney' generally assumes an attorney-client relationship, which does not exist when a lawyer proceeds pro se. Therefore, legal fees are not considered a 'cost' of litigation in the case of a pro se litigant. <end>

<context> or cannot insist that those practices are mandated. Neither the Supreme Court nor this court has ever adopted a rule limiting protection to practices that are compelled by a litigant’s religion. We decline to adopt such a rule today. C. The Impingement Threshold The fact that the First Amendment does not protect only compelled religious conduct does not mean that the Constitution forbids all constraints on religiously motivated conduct, however trivial. Instead, the First Amendment is implicated when a law or regulation imposes a substantial, as opposed to inconsequential, burden on the litigant’s religious practice. Our cases make clear that this threshold showing must be made before the First Amendment is implicated. See Branch Ministries v. Rossotti, 211 F.3d 137, 142 (D.C.Cir.2000) (<HOLDING>). This requirement accords with the Supreme <question> What is the threshold for the First Amendment to be implicated? <issues> Determining the threshold for the First Amendment to be implicated <rules> The First Amendment is implicated when a law or regulation imposes a substantial burden on the litigant's religious practice <analysis> The passage states that the First Amendment is implicated when a law or regulation imposes a substantial, as opposed to inconsequential, burden on the litigant's religious practice. This means that the Constitution does not forbid all constraints on religiously motivated conduct, but rather, the First Amendment comes into play when there is a substantial burden on religious practice. <answer> The threshold for the First Amendment to be implicated is when a law or regulation imposes a substantial burden on the litigant's religious practice. The Constitution does not protect all constraints on religiously motivated conduct, but rather, the First Amendment is concerned with cases where there is a substantial burden on religious practice. <end>

The ACLU contends that cell tower dumps violate reasonable expectations of privacy “because they involve just th[is] sort of ‘dragnet type’ surveillance of hundreds or thousands of innocent people.” (Wessler 5/20/14 Letter at 13). I cannot agree that the Government’s application here raises the spectre of “wholesale surveillance” suggested in Knotts and some of the cases following it. Such concerns center on the possibility of the Government tracking an individual’s (or a number of individuals’) every movement over a period of time. While the ACLU argues that cell tower dumps involve 'dragnet type' surveillance of innocent people, the court disagrees and states that the government's application here does not raise concerns about wholesale surveillance. <context> of the public and the defendants in a speedy trial.” Id. at 1269 (brackets omitted) (quoting 18 U.S.C. § 3161(h)(7)(A)). Defendant’s case was joined with those of several codefendants, and there were ongoing investigations in Arizona and Texas. Id. Where defendants are properly joined for trial, as here, the case’s complexity necessarily must be assessed with reference to the joint trial. United States v. Daychild, 357 F.3d 1082, 1091 (9th Cir. 2004). This case involved voluminous discovery, a large number of counts, several defendants, ongoing investigations in other districts, and potential witnesses from other countries. We have upheld “ends of justice” continuances because of complexity in similar circumstances. See, e.g., United States v. Dota, 33 F.3d 1179, 1183 (9th Cir.1994) (<HOLDING>); United States v. Butz, 982 F.2d 1378, 1381 <question> Why were 'ends of justice' continuances upheld in similar circumstances? <issues> Reason for upholding 'ends of justice' continuances in similar circumstances <rules> Legal principles governing 'ends of justice' continuances <analysis> Explain the reason for upholding 'ends of justice' continuances in similar circumstances based on the legal principles <answer> The 'ends of justice' continuances were upheld in similar circumstances because the case involved voluminous discovery, a large number of counts, several defendants, ongoing investigations in other districts, and potential witnesses from other countries. Based on similar circumstances in the past, 'ends of justice' continuances were considered necessary to ensure a fair and efficient trial process. These continuances are granted under the authority of the relevant legal provision, 18 U.S.C. § 3161(h)(7)(A), which allows for reasonable delays in criminal cases to serve the interests of justice, including complexity of the case. In this particular case, the complexity arises from the fact that multiple defendants are involved, there are ongoing investigations in different states, and there is evidence that needs to be collected from witnesses located in other countries. By granting the continuances, the court recognizes the need for sufficient time to conduct a thorough investigation, prepare for trial, and ensure the rights of the defendants to a speedy trial are balanced with the interests of justice. <end>

<context> the injury and the disability. The injury by itself does not fulfill the statutory requirement; rather, the resultant loss and disability are the key. As the Appellate Division stated in this case, a plaintiff must show that “the injury had a serious impact on the plaintiff and her life.” 250 N.J.Super. at 470, 595 A.2d 522. That requirement seems to comport with the New York cases. See, e.g., Dwyer v. Tracey, supra, 480 N.Y.S.2d at 783 (requiring plaintiff to establish “ ‘permanent loss’ ” or “ ‘permanent consequential limitation of use of a body organ or member’ ” by “competent medical proof”). The same case holds that “subjective complaints unsupported by credible medical evidence do not suffice.” Ibid.; accord Scheer v. Koubek, 70 N.Y.2d 678, 518 N.Y.S.2d 788, 512 N.E.2d 309 (1987) (<HOLDING>). Compare Waldman v. Dong Kook Chang, 175 <question> What is the requirement for establishing a serious impact on the plaintiff's life in a personal injury case? <issues> Requirement for establishing a serious impact on the plaintiff's life in a personal injury case <rules> The requirement that "the injury had a serious impact on the plaintiff and her life" as stated by the Appellate Division in the referenced case (250 N.J.Super. at 470, 595 A.2d 522) seems to comport with New York cases. New York cases, such as Dwyer v. Tracey (480 N.Y.S.2d at 783), require the plaintiff to establish "permanent loss" or "permanent consequential limitation of use of a body organ or member" by "competent medical proof". Subjective complaints unsupported by credible medical evidence do not suffice. <analysis> To establish a serious impact on the plaintiff's life in a personal injury case, the plaintiff must provide evidence that the injury resulted in a significant loss and disability. This requirement is in line with the Appellate Division's ruling and is supported by New York cases. Objective medical evidence and competent medical proof are necessary to substantiate the plaintiff's claims. <answer> In a personal injury case, the requirement for establishing a serious impact on the plaintiff's life is that the injury must result in a significant loss and disability. This was stated by the Appellate Division in the referenced case, and it is consistent with the requirements in New York cases. The plaintiff must provide objective medical evidence and competent medical proof to support their claims, as subjective complaints alone are not sufficient. <end>

Ernst & Young, 95 F.3d 821 (9th Cir.1996) (accountant liable for providing fraudulent audit report to corporation). <analysis> Based on the legal authorities cited, the test for holding defendants directly liable for their own misleading statements to analysts is that they cannot escape liability by using third parties to carry out the fraud, and can be held liable if they themselves make misleading statements to analysts. <answer> The test for holding defendants directly liable for their own misleading statements to analysts is that they cannot escape liability simply because they carried out the alleged fraud through the public statements of third parties. This principle was established in the case of Warshaw v. Xoma Corp., where the court ruled that defendants can be held liable for their own misleading statements to analysts. Additionally, in the case of McGann v. Ernst & Young, an accountant was held liable for providing a fraudulent audit report to a corporation, which was then distributed to investors. These cases establish that defendants can be held directly liable for their own misleading statements to analysts. <end>

<context> “established a duty to support a child” may refer to a trial court’s original order creating a child support obligation. On the other hand, the language could be read to refer to the most recent order establishing a child support obligation, which also defines the duty to support. Our view is that our General Assembly intended the latter. At the outset, we make two observations regarding Indiana Code section 31-16-6-6 that guide us in our interpretation. First, there is no common law duty for a parent to support his or her able-bodied adult child. Novak v. Chicago & Calumet Dist. Transit Co., 235 Ind. 489, 493, 135 N.E.2d 1, 3 (1956). Nor does Indiana impose a common law duty to provide a child with a college education. Haag v. Haag, 240 Ind. 291, 303-05, 163 N.E.2d 243, 248-49 (1959) (<HOLDING>). Thus, to the extent that Indiana Code section <question> What does 'established a duty to support a child' refer to in Indiana Code section 31-16-6-6? <issues> The interpretation of the phrase 'established a duty to support a child' in Indiana Code section 31-16-6-6. <rules> There is no common law duty for a parent to support able-bodied adult children and no common law duty to provide a child with a college education in Indiana. <analysis> The phrase 'established a duty to support a child' in Indiana Code section 31-16-6-6 can refer to either a trial court's original order creating a child support obligation or the most recent order establishing a child support obligation. However, the interpretation favored by the General Assembly is that it refers to the latter, which also defines the duty to support. <answer> The phrase 'established a duty to support a child' in Indiana Code section 31-16-6-6 can be interpreted in two ways: it could refer to a trial court's original order creating a child support obligation, or it could refer to the most recent order establishing a child support obligation. However, the interpretation favored by the General Assembly is that it refers to the latter, which also defines the duty to support. It is important to note that Indiana does not impose a common law duty for a parent to support able-bodied adult children or to provide a child with a college education. <end>

<context> Precision, Inc, 469 Mich 362, 374; 666 NW2d 251 (2003). An affirmative expression of assent constitutes a waiver. Id. at 378. In contrast, a failure to timely assert a right constitutes a forfeiture. Id. at 379. “A stipulation is an agreement, admission or concession made by the parties in a legal action with regard to a matter related to the case.” People v Metamora Water Serv, Inc, 276 Mich App 376, 385; 741 NW2d 61 (2007). To waive a right, the language of a stipulation must show an intent to plainly relinquish that right. Whitley v Chrysler Corp, 373 Mich 469, 474; 130 NW2d 26 (1964). However, the use of specific key words is not required to waive a right. See Amalgamated Transit Union, Local 1564, AFL-CIO v Southeastern Mich Transp Auth, 437 Mich 441, 463 n 16; 473 NW2d 249 (1991) (<HOLDING>). In this case, in November 2013, Mando <question> What does it mean for an affirmative expression of assent to constitute a waiver? <issues> Meaning of an affirmative expression of assent constituting a waiver <rules> Legal principle stated in Precision, Inc, 469 Mich 362, 374; 666 NW2d 251 (2003) <analysis> An affirmative expression of assent constitutes a waiver, as stated in Precision, Inc, 469 Mich 362, 374; 666 NW2d 251 (2003). This means that when a party explicitly expresses their agreement or consent to waive a certain right, they are giving up that right. The intention to relinquish the right must be clear from the language used in the expression of assent. <answer> When a party explicitly expresses their agreement or consent to waive a certain right, this is referred to as an affirmative expression of assent constituting a waiver. It means that the party is willingly relinquishing the right in question. This principle is stated in Precision, Inc, 469 Mich 362, 374; 666 NW2d 251 (2003). The language of the waiver must clearly show the intent to give up the right, and the specific key words are not required for the waiver to be valid. <end>

<context> moves into the realm of res judicata.”). The doctrine of issue preclusion “comes into play when an issue involved in a prior decision is the same issue involved in a subsequent action.” See Mabry v. State Bd. of Community Colleges & Occupational Educ., 813 F.2d 311, 316 (10th Cir.1987). If the bankruptcy court’s turnover order, which the debtors did not appeal, “actually and necessarily decided” the exemption issue, principles of issue preclusion could prevent the debtors from raising this argument in an appeal from a subsequent order. See id. (noting that issue preclusion does not apply unless “the issue is actually decided in the first action” and “it was necessary to decide the issue in disposing of the first action”); see also In re Albrecht, 233 F.3d 1258, 1260-61 (10th Cir.2000) (<HOLDING>); Turshen v. Chapman, 823 F.2d 836, 839 (4th <question> What is issue preclusion and how does it apply in the context of the bankruptcy court's turnover order? <issues> Understanding the concept of issue preclusion and its application in subsequent actions. <rules> The doctrine of issue preclusion applies when an issue involved in a prior decision is the same issue involved in a subsequent action. <analysis> In this case, if the bankruptcy court's turnover order actually and necessarily decided the exemption issue and the debtors did not appeal it, principles of issue preclusion could prevent the debtors from raising this argument in an appeal from a subsequent order. <answer> Issue preclusion, also known as collateral estoppel, is a legal doctrine that comes into play when an issue involved in a prior decision is the same issue involved in a subsequent action. It prevents the relitigation of issues that have already been decided in a previous case, promoting judicial efficiency and finality of judgments. In the context of the bankruptcy court's turnover order, if the exemption issue was actually and necessarily decided in the previous order and the debtors did not appeal it, the principles of issue preclusion could prevent the debtors from raising the same argument in an appeal from a subsequent order. This means that the exemption issue is considered resolved and cannot be challenged again in the subsequent action. <end>

We hold that Dr. Johnson has failed to present evidence of reasonable reliance, and thus her promissory estoppel claim fails. The district court granted summary judgment on this claim on the ground that it was barred by the statute of frauds. Georgia law is unclear regarding whether the statute of frauds can defeat a claim of promissory estoppel. See Eric Mills Holmes, Restatement of Promissory Estoppel, 32 Willamette L.Rev. 263, 367-69 (1996) (attempting to summarize Georgia law on promissory estoppel and expressing confusion over whether Georgia recognizes the doctrine as a defense to a statute of frauds argument). City of Bainbridge, 172 Ga.App. <question> Can the statute of frauds defeat a claim of promissory estoppel under Georgia law? <issues> Whether the statute of frauds can be used as a defense against a claim of promissory estoppel under Georgia law. <rules> The district court held that the statute of frauds can defeat a claim of promissory estoppel, but Georgia law is unclear on this issue. The district court granted summary judgment on this claim, citing the statute of frauds as a bar. However, the passage also states that Georgia law is unclear on whether the statute of frauds can defeat a claim of promissory estoppel. Therefore, it is uncertain whether the statute of frauds can be used as a defense against a claim of promissory estoppel under Georgia law. <answer> Under Georgia law, it is unclear whether the statute of frauds can defeat a claim of promissory estoppel. While the district court in Dr. Johnson's case held that the statute of frauds barred her promissory estoppel claim, there are conflicting decisions in Georgia courts on this issue. Some cases have held that the statute of frauds does not apply to promissory estoppel claims. Therefore, it depends on the specific facts and circumstances of each case whether the statute of frauds can be used as a defense against a claim of promissory estoppel under Georgia law. <end>

This is because a “prevailing plaintiff ... should ordinarily recover an attorney’s fee unless special circumstances would render such an award unjust.” Barrios, 277 F.3d at 1134 (9th Cir.2002). The Ninth Circuit has held that an ADA plaintiff is a prevailing party if she: (1) “achieve[s] a material alteration of the legal relationship of the parties”; and (2) that alteration is “judicially sanctioned.” Jankey v. <context> unnamed plaintiffs are the real parties in interest. See Navarro, 446 U.S. at 461, 100 S.Ct. 1779. A court may not consider a plaintiff-State a “citizen” for diversity jurisdiction purposes if the State is a real party in interest. Nuclear Eng’g Co., 660 F.2d at 250 (citing Ford, 323 U.S. at 464, 65 S.Ct. 347). A State is a real party in interest when it “articulate[s] an interest apart from the interests of particular private parties, i.e., the State must be more than a nominal party. The State must express a quasi-sovereign interest.” Illinois v. Life of Mid-America Ins. Co., 805 F.2d 763, 766 (7th Cir.1986) (quoting Alfred L. Snapp & Son, Inc. v. Puerto Rico, 458 U.S. 592, 607, 102 S.Ct. 3260, 73 L.Ed.2d 995 (1982)) (emphasis added); see also SDS West Corp., 640 F.Supp.2d at 1050 (<HOLDING>). This means that the State must articulate a quasi-sovereign interest, indicating that it has a distinct and separate interest from private parties involved in the litigation. This criteria was established in the case of Illinois v. Life of Mid-America Ins. Co., where the court quoted Alfred L. Snapp & Son, Inc. v. Puerto Rico in stating that the State must express a quasi-sovereign interest. <answer> For a State to be considered a real party in interest, it must articulate an interest that is separate from the interests of individual private parties. This means that the State must express a quasi-sovereign interest, indicating that it has a distinct and separate interest from private parties involved in the litigation. This criteria was established in the case of Illinois v. Life of Mid-America Ins. Co., where the court quoted Alfred L. Snapp & Son, Inc. v. Puerto Rico in stating that the State must express a quasi-sovereign interest. <end>

<context> 389 (D.C.Cir.1996). Before an action may be brought in the district court, a FOIA requester must exhaust administrative remedies in order to give the agency “an opportunity to exercise its discretion and expertise on the matter and to make a factual record to support its decision.” Hidalgo v. FBI, 344 F.3d 1256, 1258-59 (D.C.Cir.2003). While exhaustion is not a jurisdictional requirement, “as a jurisprudential doctrine, failure to exhaust precludes judicial review if ‘the purposes of exhaustion’ and the ‘particular administrative scheme’ support such a bar.” Id. As “the FOIA’s administrative scheme favors treating failure to exhaust as a bar to judicial review,” failure to exhaust is a prudential requirement in the FOIA context. Id.; Wilbur v. CIA, 355 F.3d 675, 676-77 (D.C.Cir.2004) (<HOLDING>) (internal quotation marks omitted). If a FOIA <question> What is the purpose of exhausting administrative remedies in a FOIA context? <issues> The purpose of exhausting administrative remedies in a FOIA context. <rules> The FOIA's administrative scheme favors treating failure to exhaust as a bar to judicial review. <analysis> Exhausting administrative remedies in a FOIA context allows the agency to exercise its discretion and expertise, make a factual record to support its decision, and create an administrative scheme that supports judicial review. <answer> The purpose of exhausting administrative remedies in a FOIA context is to give the agency the opportunity to exercise its discretion and expertise, make a factual record to support its decision, and create an administrative scheme that supports judicial review. Failure to exhaust administrative remedies may preclude judicial review if the purposes of exhaustion and the particular administrative scheme support such a bar. This means that a FOIA requester must complete the administrative process before bringing an action in the district court. <end>

<context> court’s dismissal for mootness de novo”). [¶ 10] A trial court properly dismisses a case for mootness if the case “has lost its character as edication). [¶ 15] Common-law dedication requires, (1) an intention to dedicate and, (2) public acceptance of the dedication. Cole, 17 N.D. 409, 117 N.W. at 358. Intent to dedicate, “is to be ascertained from the acts of the owner, and not from the purpose hidden in his mind.... Dedications have been established in every conceivable way by which the intention of the party can be manifested.” Ramstad v. Carr, 31 N.D. 504, 154 N.W. 195, 199 (N.D.1915) (citation omitted); Cole, at 358 (stating, “the intention to dedicate be properly and clearly manifested”); Security Federal Savings & Loan Ass’n v. C & C Investments, 448 N.W.2d 83, 87 (Minn.App.1989) (<HOLDING>). [¶ 16] A common-law dedication must be proven <question> What are the requirements for a common-law dedication to be proven? <issues> Requirements for common-law dedication <rules> Intention to dedicate and public acceptance <analysis> For a common-law dedication to be proven, there must be an intention to dedicate, which is to be ascertained from the acts of the owner. Public acceptance of the dedication is also required. The intention to dedicate must be properly and clearly manifested, and dedications can be established in various ways. <answer> To prove a common-law dedication, there must be an intention to dedicate, which can be determined by the acts of the owner. Public acceptance of the dedication is also necessary. The intention to dedicate must be properly and clearly manifested, and there are no fixed rules for how dedication can be established. <end>

The implementing regulations to the above Section note that a reviewing court may only address matters on appeal of a Notice of Determination that were raised by the taxpayer at the collection due process hearing. 26 C.F.R. § 301.6380-1(f)(2) Q-F5/A-F5 (stating that “the taxpayer can only ask the court to consider an issue that was raised in the taxpayer’s CDP hearing”). Courts interpreting these provisions have determined that actions brought pursuant to § 6330(d) are actions for administrative review and, thus, the reviewing district court is limited to the administrative record and the parties are not entitled to discovery or jury trial. See e.g. Community Residential Services, Inc. v. U.S., 2003 WL 21033239 at * 1 (M.D.N.C. May 7, 2003) (<HOLDING>); Carroll v. The Court noted that in Tull, it was “presented with no evidence that juries historically had determined the amount of civil penalties to be paid to the [government,” while in Feltner there was “clear and direct historical evidence that juries, both as a general matter and in copyright cases, set the amount of damages awarded to a successful plaintiff.” Id. at 354-55, 118 S.Ct. 1279. <context> these decisions and their reasoning. The sex discrimination provisions of Title VII and the ICRA were enacted to stop the perpetuation of sexist or chauvinistic attitudes in employment which significantly affect employment opportunities. Title VII and the ICRA were not meant to prohibit employers from instituting personal grooming codes which have a de minimis affect on employment. Applying these principles to Fareway’s unwritten personal grooming code, we conclude this grooming code did not constitute discrimination based on sex within the meaning of Title VII or the ICRA. This grooming code was never intended to be covered by Title VII’s or ICRA’s prohibition against discrimination on the basis of sex. See Kleinsorge v. Eyeland Corp., 81 Fair Empl. Prac. Cas. <context> There must be some “clear indication that the trial court intended the order to completely dispose of the entire case." Id. at 205. More specifically, a judgment is final for purposes of appeal when (1) a judgment expressly disposes of some, but not all defendants, (2) the only remaining defendants have not been served or answered, and (3) nothing in the record indicates that plaintiff ever expected to obtain service on the unserved defendants, such that the case “stands as if there had been a discontinuance” as to the unserved defendants. In re Sheppard, 193 S.W.3d 181,187 (Tex.App.-Houston [1st Dist.] 2006, orig. proceeding) (quoting Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co. v. Penn, 363 S.W.2d 230, 232 (Tex.1962)); see also M.O. Dental Lab v. Rape, 139 S.W.3d 671, 674-75 (Tex.2004) (per curiam) (<HOLDING>)', In re Miranda, 142 S.W.3d 354, 357 <question> What conditions must be met for a judgment to be considered final for purposes of appeal? <issues> Determining the conditions for a judgment to be considered final for purposes of appeal <rules> The conditions are: (1) a judgment expressly disposes of some, but not all defendants, (2) the only remaining defendants have not been served or answered, and (3) nothing in the record indicates that plaintiff ever expected to obtain service on the unserved defendants <analysis> To determine if a judgment is final for purposes of appeal, we need to evaluate if all three conditions are met. If the judgment does not meet all three conditions, it cannot be considered final for purposes of appeal. <answer> In order for a judgment to be considered final for purposes of appeal, it must meet three conditions: (1) a judgment expressly disposes of some, but not all defendants; (2) the only remaining defendants have not been served or answered; and (3) nothing in the record indicates that the plaintiff ever expected to obtain service on the unserved defendants. If any of these conditions are not met, the judgment cannot be considered final for purposes of appeal. <end>

Although the parking garage is located directly beneath the entire apartment building, it does not make Dumstrey's home closely proximate to the garage. Dumstrey occupies only one unit within the building, which is different from a single family home's attached garage that is typically considered part of the home's curtilage. <end>

Federal courts routinely dismiss claims attacking a verdict as against the weight of the evidence on the basis that they are not federal constitutional issues cognizable in a habeas proceeding. The Testimony Regarding Cocaine Use As mentioned above, defendant unsuccessfully moved for a mistrial after Dennis Fullen unexpectedly exclaimed on cross examination that he frequently engaged in the illegal drug trade with defendant. <context> a “catchall exception” that allows hearsay to be admitted in cases in which the declarant testifies if certain conditions are satisfied, the key one being that there are circumstantial guarantees of trustworthiness equivalent to those surrounding statements fitting within the 23 specific exceptions created by Rule 803. Rule 803(24) is identical to Rule 804(b)(5), which is the corresponding “catchall exception” to be used when the declarant is unavailable. See State v. Posten, 302 N.W.2d 638, 641 (Minn.1981). We have considered either Rule 803(24) or 804(b)(5) in a number of cases, including: State v. Langley, 354 N.W.2d 389 (Minn.1984) (admission of hearsay accounts of prior assaults upon homicide victim by defendant under Rule 804(b)(5)); State v. Hansen, 312 N.W.2d 96 (Minn.1981) (<HOLDING>); State v. Posten, 302 N.W.2d 638 (Minn.1981) <question> What is the purpose of the 'catchall exception' in the rules of evidence? <issues> Purpose of the 'catchall exception' <rules> Rule 803(24) and Rule 804(b)(5) <analysis> The 'catchall exception' allows for the admission of hearsay in certain cases. The key condition for its application is that there must be circumstantial guarantees of trustworthiness equivalent to those surrounding the specific exceptions created by Rule 803. Rule 803(24) is applicable when the declarant testifies, while Rule 804(b)(5) is used when the declarant is unavailable. The purpose of these rules is to provide a pathway for the admission of hearsay evidence that does not fit within the specific exceptions, but still meets the requirement of trustworthiness. <answer> The purpose of the 'catchall exception' in the rules of evidence, as defined in Rule 803(24) and Rule 804(b)(5), is to allow for the admission of hearsay in cases where the declarant testifies or is unavailable, respectively, provided that there are circumstantial guarantees of trustworthiness equivalent to those surrounding the specific exceptions created by Rule 803. This exception serves as a means to admit hearsay evidence that does not fit within the specific exceptions, but still meets the requirement of trustworthiness. <end>
